questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She reports dull aching pain and paresthesia over her left hand for the last few weeks. The pain radiates to her shoulder and is worse at night. Her hand feels numb upon waking up in the morning. She has a sister who has multiple sclerosis. Her current medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the wrist is passively held in full flexion, aggravation of paresthesia is perceived immediately. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Lower trunk palsy of the brachial plexus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paralysis of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Klumpke palsy) causes deficits along the C8 and T1 myotomes and dermatomes. Although Klumpke palsy may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand and would also be present on the ulnar aspect of the forearm. Hand and finger weakness is also typically prominent. In addition, this patient lacks a history that would suggest Klumpke paralysis (e.g., upward traction on the arm, thoracic outlet syndrome, Pancoast tumor).

B) INCORRECT:

Compression of the ulnar nerve in the ulnar groove between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon (cubital tunnel syndrome) may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand as seen in this patient. However, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand, and/or the ring and little finger and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with ulnar nerve compression. Also, this patient has no history that would suggest a cubital tunnel syndrome (e.g., osteoarthritis or trauma to the elbow).
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

C) INCORRECT:

Radiculopathy of C6, C7, and/or C8 nerve roots may manifest with pain and paresthesia in the hand and shoulder. However, radiculopathy is typically accompanied by restriction of neck, arm, or hand movements. Also, nocturnal paresthesia is usually not present. Exacerbation of paresthesia by passive flexion of the wrist (Phalen sign) suggests a specific mononeuropathy and not radiculopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Immune-mediated demyelinating neuropathies such as Guillain-Barre syndrome can manifest with pain and paresthesias affecting the distal extremities. However, these sensory abnormalities are generally symmetric and associated with concurrent ascending flaccid muscle paralysis that begins in the lower limbs. The presence of an asymmetric sensory disorder that is localized to the hand and the absence of motor deficits suggest a different diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel (carpal tunnel syndrome, CTS) results in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the areas innervated by the median nerve (i.e., palmar surface of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, and radial half of the ring finger). Pregnancy is an important risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome because of physiological fluid retention, which leads to edema of soft tissue in and around the carpal tunnel. The sensory disturbances in CTS are classically worse at night and pain on flexion of the wrist (a positive Phalen test) may be present. Occasionally, the pain may radiate to the shoulder, as seen in this patient. Most cases of carpal tunnel syndrome with an onset during pregnancy can be managed by splinting of the wrist. Surgery and corticosteroid injections are usually not required because symptoms usually resolve after delivery.
Image Description:

The Phalen maneuver is considered specific for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The examiner holds the patient's wrist in flexion (1) or extension (2). If paresthesia in the fingers innervated by the median nerve (marked in white) occurs or is aggravated within one minute, this finding is highly specific for CTS.

F) INCORRECT:

Radial nerve compression usually results from trauma or prolonged pressure on the mid-arm (e.g., Saturday night palsy). Radial nerve palsy typically manifests with sensory changes over the posterior forearm/hand and weakness on wrist extension (i.e., wrist drop). This patient has no significant risk factors for radial nerve compression (e.g., trauma or intoxication) and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with radial nerve compression.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP joints

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2nd and 3rd fingers. The 1st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumb

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

G) INCORRECT:

Demyelinating diseases of the CNS such as multiple sclerosis (MS) may manifest with a variety of neurologic symptoms, including arm paresthesias. While this patient is at increased risk for MS (woman of childbearing age with a positive family history), the association of her symptoms with sleep, its presence during pregnancy, and exacerbation with wrist flexion are inconsistent with MS. MS should be suspected if there are recurrent neurologic symptoms in different parts of the body (e.g., wrist paresthesia that resolves, followed by diplopia months later). MS exacerbations tend to cause symptoms that are persistent for days to weeks, until the flare resolves. Finally, MS symptoms tend to improve during pregnancy (possibly due to immunosuppression).
questions.hint: Beside pregnancy, hypothyroidism and rheumatoid arthritis are also risk factors for this patient's condition.

questions.text: Eighteen hours after the vaginal delivery of a 2788-g (6-lb 2-oz) newborn, a 22-year-old woman has weakness and numbness of her right foot. She is unable to walk without dragging and shuffling her foot. The delivery was complicated by prolonged labor and the patient had received epidural analgesia. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a high-stepping gait. There is weakness upon right foot dorsiflexion and right ankle eversion. Sensation is decreased over the dorsum of the right foot and the anterolateral aspect of the right lower extremity below the knee. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Compression of the common peroneal nerve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pregnant women are at an increased risk of lumbar radiculopathy, as an increase in body weight and mechanical stress when bending puts pressure on a pre-existing bulging or herniated disk in the lower back. However, L2–L4 radiculopathy causes weakness of the hip flexors, knee extensors, and ankle dorsiflexors, while this patient only has weakness of ankle dorsiflexion. Furthermore, lumbar radiculopathy manifests with a diminished patellar reflex, whereas this patient has intact reflexes, suggesting a peripheral nerve lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

Epidural anesthesia affects sensory nerve fibers more than motor nerve fibers, effectively providing analgesia without severely impairing a patient's ability to move. Additional doses of anesthesia are required every one to two hours as the body metabolizes the local anesthetic. Given that this patient has not received any additional epidural doses since delivery 18 hours ago, it is highly unlikely that the epidural anesthesia is the cause of her sensory and motor symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of postpartum angiopathy include headache, focal deficits, visual disturbances, encephalopathy, and seizure within 1–2 weeks of delivery. It is a rare cause of stroke in the acute postpartum period. However, this patient has focal neurological symptoms in the pattern of a single nerve distribution.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a high-stepping gait, weakness of foot eversion and dorsiflexion, and decreased sensation in the anterolateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot, which is consistent with common peroneal nerve injury, the most common peripheral nerve lesion of the lower extremity. Because it descends along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the head of the fibula, the common peroneal nerve is susceptible to injury during obstetric procedures (See “Obstetric nerve injuries” table). It is likely that this nerve was accidentally compressed during childbirth, especially given the prolonged second stage of labor.

Treatment of peroneal nerve injuries involves removal of the underlying cause (loosening a tight-fitting cast, avoidance of sitting cross-legged). Symptoms are usually self-limited once the cause of the compression is removed. In some cases, corticosteroids may be recommended to reduce swelling and inflammation that is causing compression of the nerve. If the symptoms persist, surgical decompression may be necessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Because of its location in the pelvis under the inguinal ligament, the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury from compression due to increased intra-abdominal pressure from pregnancy, obesity, or prolonged pushing with hip flexion during labor. Although this patient had multiple risk factors for lateral femoral cutaneous nerve injury, the condition manifests with sensory loss over the lateral thigh on the affected side and no motor deficit.
questions.hint: The semi-Fowler lithotomy position (legs flexed at the hips, abducted, and externally rotated), forceful knee flexion, and use of obstetrical stirrups are common during childbirth and put mothers at risk for a specific nerve lesion.

questions.text: A previously healthy 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and intermittent numbness in her right thigh for the past 2 months. She reports that her symptoms are worse when walking or standing and are better while sitting. Three months ago, she started going to a fitness class a couple of times per week. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 88 kg (194 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the skin shows no abnormalities. Sensation to light touch is decreased over the lateral aspect of the right anterior thigh. Muscle strength is normal. Tapping the right inguinal ligament leads to increased numbness of the affected thigh. The straight leg test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Advise patient to wear looser pants

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the lumbar spine can detect nerve root impingement from disk herniation. Although impingement of the L2 nerve root may result in lateral thigh pain, isolated L2 radiculopathy is extremely rare (95% of disk herniations occur at the L4-L5 and L5-S1 level). This patient also lacks the back pain that is typically associated with disk herniation and has a negative straight leg raise.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein) and leukocytosis might indicate osteomyelitis of the hip, which can manifest with subacute hip and thigh pain without fever or constitutional symptoms, as in this patient. However, this patient lacks any risk factors for osteomyelitis (diabetes, vasculopathy, recent procedures, or IV drug use). Osteomyelitis of the hip would not explain her sensory loss in the distribution of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve.

C) CORRECT:

The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve runs under the inguinal ligament and is at risk of compression when pressure is placed on the ligament. Chronic compression may lead to sensory symptoms (known as meralgia paresthetica) and is more common in obese or pregnant individuals and/or in those who wear tight pants or belts. In most patients, advice to mitigate aggravating factors (e.g., tight pants or belts) or lose weight (in the case of obese individuals) is all that is required. Compression of the nerve due to pregnancy typically resolves after delivery.

D) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the hip can detect more advanced forms of avascular necrosis of the femoral head (AVN). However, AVN more commonly manifests with groin pain, which is usually present at rest, and difficulty bearing weight on the affected side. This patient also lacks the usual risk factors of AVN, such as chronic corticosteroid therapy, sickle cell anemia, or alcohol abuse. Importantly, the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is usually not affected in AVN of the hip.

E) INCORRECT:

Reducing physical activity can allow musculoskeletal injuries causing thigh pain to heal. Although this patient could have sustained a musculoskeletal injury in her fitness class, her lateral thigh numbness suggests a nerve impingement under the inguinal ligament, which would not resolve with reduction of physical activity. In fact, losing weight through regular physical activity would likely help improve her symptoms.
questions.hint: This obese patient presents with pain and paresthesias in the lateral anterior thigh without motor findings, which suggests lateral femoral cutaneous syndrome (meralgia paresthetica). Reproduction of numbness when tapping on the inguinal ligament supports this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of new-onset limping. For the past 2 weeks, she has had a tendency to trip over her left foot unless she lifts her left leg higher while walking. She has not had any trauma to the leg. She works as a flight attendant and wears compression stockings to work. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows weakness of left foot dorsiflexion against minimal resistance. There is reduced sensation to light touch over the dorsum of the left foot, including the web space between the 1st and 2nd digit. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A decreased ankle jerk reflex can be seen in S1 radiculopathy. However, S1 radiculopathy typically manifests with a motor deficit in plantar flexion, which this patient does not have.

B) INCORRECT:

The superficial branch of the peroneal nerve controls foot eversion. It innervates the peroneus longus and peroneus brevis muscles, which are the primary foot evertors. Because this patient's nerve compression occurs before the branching point of the peroneal nerve, the superficial peroneal nerve is likely affected, resulting in weak foot eversion.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with peroneal neuropathy, the most common peripheral nerve lesion of the lower extremity. Patients with this condition have normal foot inversion because the primary muscle responsible for foot inversion (tibialis posterior) is not innervated by the peroneal nerve. Compression of the peroneal nerve usually occurs just distal to the knee as the nerve wraps around the lateral aspect of the head of the fibula. Wearing compression stockings can predispose to peroneal compression (due to increased pressure at the fibular head). The deep peroneal nerve, one branch of the common peroneal nerve, innervates the tibialis anterior, which acts to both dorsiflex and invert the foot. However, it is much less important for foot inversion than the tibialis posterior is, so inversion is typically unaffected.

D) INCORRECT:

A decreased patellar reflex would be seen in L4 radiculopathy. This nerve root is primarily responsible for foot dorsiflexion and sensation from the distal lateral thigh to the medial lower leg. Though this patient's difficulty in dorsiflexing her left foot is consistent with L4 radiculopathy, her sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot and the web space between the 1st and 2nd digit would only be found with a common peroneal nerve injury. In a patient with weak foot dorsiflexion and numbness of the lateral thigh or medial leg, or weak patellar reflex, L4 radiculopathy should be suspected.

E) INCORRECT:

Weak knee flexion may be seen in sciatic nerve injury, which would manifest with an extended leg and gait abnormalities secondary to hamstring muscle weakness, and may cause numbness over the posterior leg. Sciatic injury would not lead to foot drop, high-stepping gait, weakness in dorsiflexion, or dorsal foot numbness.

F) INCORRECT:

Weak hip flexion can be caused by femoral nerve injury, which would manifest with weak knee extension and numbness over the anteromedial portion of the thigh and leg. This patient's sensory deficit is indicative of common peroneal nerve injury, which would not cause hip weakness.

G) INCORRECT:

Weak plantar flexion is most commonly seen with injury of the tibial nerve since it supplies the posterior compartment of the leg, where the most powerful plantar flexors are (e.g., gastrocnemius, soleus). Tibial nerve injury causes an inability to walk on the toes or balls of the feet, not foot drop.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has common peroneal neuropathy because she presents with a foot drop (high stepping gait, weakness of foot dorsiflexion) and numbness in the distribution of both the superficial and deep peroneal nerves (dorsum of the foot and first web space, respectively).

questions.text: A 4390-g (9-lb 11-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus. Labor was prolonged by the impaction of the fetal shoulder and required hyperabduction of the left upper extremity. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination in the delivery room shows a constricted left pupil. There is drooping of the left eyelid. Active movement of the left upper extremity is reduced. Further evaluation of this newborn is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Decreased movement of unilateral rib cage

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Moderate to severe hypoxic encephalopathy will cause generalized hypotonia. Although this patient's complicated birthing process puts him at increased risk for hypoxic encephalopathy due to perinatal asphyxia, other findings would also be expected in this condition (e.g., lethargy, decreased response to physical stimuli, and/or irregular breathing), which are not evident given his high Apgar scores.

B) INCORRECT:

Crepitus in the upper chest suggests a clavicular fracture for which this infant is at increased risk because of his traumatic birthing process. Although a clavicular fracture is usually asymptomatic, it can manifest as pseudoparalysis with reduced movement of the arm (due to pain), as seen in this infant. However, the presence of ptosis and miosis suggests a brachial plexus injury and not pseudoparalysis.

C) INCORRECT:

A unilateral wrist drop can occur after injury to the radial nerve (e.g., mid-shaft fracture of the humerus) or injury to the posterior cord of the brachial plexus (e.g., penetrating trauma below the clavicle). However, neither radial nerve injury nor posterior cord injury would manifest with ptosis and miosis, which suggests that this patient has a different brachial plexus injury.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP joints

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2nd and 3rd fingers. The 1st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumb

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

D) INCORRECT:

An absent nasolabial fold suggests a cranial nerve (CN) VII injury, which most commonly results from a forceps-assisted delivery. Although this patient has other facial abnormalities (ptosis and miosis), these findings are due to sympathetic nerve injury originating from the brachial plexus. CN VII fibers do not run within the brachial plexus, and thus facial droop is not associated with this condition.

E) CORRECT:

Klumpke palsy is due to injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8–T1), which can result from hyperabduction (excessive upward traction) of the arm during delivery. Concurrent injury to cervical sympathetic fibers may result in Horner syndrome (miosis and ptosis). Since C8 and T1 nerve fibers supply the ipsilateral intrinsic hand muscles, Klumpke palsy causes an absent grasp reflex. Treatment for Klumpke palsy consists of passive range of motion exercises, and most infants will gain normal strength within the first couple of months of life.

F) INCORRECT:

Spina bifida cystica can manifest with a lower back mass due to protrusion of the meninges (i.e., meningocele) and spinal cord (i.e., myelomeningocele). Although these patients will have symptoms of spinal cord dysfunction, spina bifida cystica of the lower cord would cause lower extremity weakness, not unilateral arm deficits and facial sympathetic nerve dysfunction, as seen in this infant.

G) INCORRECT:

Unilateral phrenic nerve palsy can cause decreased movement of the ipsilateral rib cage and respiratory distress in the newborn. Phrenic nerve palsy can be a rare complication of a brachial plexus injury. Although this infant has evidence of brachial plexus injury (i.e., ptosis, miosis, decreased arm movement), he has no respiratory issues and normal vital signs, making phrenic nerve palsy unlikely.
questions.hint: Shoulder dystocia is a complication that can occur in macrosomic neonates born to mothers with diabetes mellitus. Obstetric maneuvers used to help deliver babies with shoulder dystocia can cause brachial plexus injury.

questions.text: Three hours after undergoing left hip arthroplasty for chronic hip pain, a 62-year-old man has a prickling sensation in his left anteromedial thigh and lower leg. He has never had these symptoms before. He has hyperlipidemia and coronary artery disease. He has had recent right-sided gluteal and thigh pain with ambulation. Vital signs are within normal limits. On neurologic examination, muscle strength is 3/5 on left hip flexion and 2/5 on left knee extension. Patellar reflex is decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch are decreased on the anteromedial left thigh and the medial lower leg. Dorsalis pedis, popliteal, and femoral pulses are 2+ bilaterally. The surgical incision is without erythema or drainage. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibular nerve injury usually results from injuries in the lower leg (e.g. fracture of the fibular head or tight-fitting casts of the lower leg). It typically manifests with foot drop (weakness of foot dorsiflexors) and a loss of sensation between the first and second toe (deep peroneal nerve branch) and the back of the feet and toes (superficial peroneal nerve branch). Fibular nerve injury would not cause loss of sensation in the anteromedial thigh or decreased strength of knee extension.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiculopathy refers to nerve root damage or irritation and usually results from degenerative joint disease of the spine or disk herniation. L5 radiculopathy typically causes back pain that radiates down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot, with sensory loss along the lateral aspect of the lower leg and dorsum of the foot, and strength deficits in foot dorsiflexion and eversion. This patient's symptoms are localized to different areas and do not follow a radicular pattern.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiculopathy refers to nerve root damage or irritation and usually results from degenerative joint disease of the spine or disk herniation. S1 radiculopathy typically causes back pain that usually radiates down the posterior leg into the foot, with sensory loss along the lateral foot, weakness in plantar flexion and eversion, and decreased Achilles tendon reflex. This patient's symptoms are localized to different areas and do not follow a radicular pattern.

D) INCORRECT:

Obturator nerve injury usually results from pelvic ring fractures or entrapment. It typically manifests with loss of sensation of the medial thigh (cutaneous branch of the obturator nerve) and decreased strength in the hip adductors. It would not explain the loss of sensation of the anterior thigh or the decreased strength in knee extension in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has evidence of femoral nerve injury, likely from prolonged compression during his surgical procedure. Injury of the femoral nerve typically results in loss of sensation in the anteromedial thigh and medial lower leg (anterior cutaneous branches), as well as decreased strength in hip flexion (iliopsoas muscle) and knee extension (quadriceps femoris muscle).

F) INCORRECT:

Sural nerve injury usually results from Achilles tendon rupture, entrapment, or ganglion lipomas. It is a purely sensory nerve and typically manifests with decreased sensation on the posterolateral lower leg and the lateral border of the foot. It would not explain the loss of sensation on the anteromedial thigh and decreased strength in knee extension seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Postoperative anteromedial thigh and lower leg paresthesias with concurrent decreased patellar reflex, hip flexion, and knee extension are consistent with damage to a peripheral nerve of the anterior lower extremity.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after he was involved in a motor vehicle accident. He complains of pain in his right shoulder. Physical examination shows bruising and tenderness to palpation just below the right coracoid process. He is unable to flex the right elbow or supinate the right forearm against resistance. There is decreased sensation to light touch over the anterolateral forearm. Which of the following labeled structures of the brachial plexus is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Traumatic damage to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5–C6) manifests with Erb palsy, which also causes impaired flexion and supination of the forearm. However, the sensory loss expected would not only occur over the lateral arm but extend to the thumb. Moreover, impaired external rotation, abduction, and wrist extension would also be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Damage to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8–T1) occurs through hyperabduction trauma. It results in Klumpke deformity and a characteristic claw hand, which results in impaired flexion of the MCP with an inability to extend the DIP and PIP joints. Moreover, damage to the plexus is accompanied by a sensory loss over the little finger and medial surface of forearm and arm. This patient's presentation is not consistent with an injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus.

C) INCORRECT:

Damage to the long thoracic nerve (C5–C7) is seen in trauma to the posterior scapular and axillary regions (e.g., in mastectomies with axillary node dissection). It results in impairment of the serratus anterior muscle and a winged scapula. Another feature is impaired arm abduction beyond 90 degrees. This patient's presentation is not consistent with long thoracic nerve injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Damage to the posterior cord of the brachial plexus (C5–T1) is seen in forceful traction injuries. This structure gives rise to the radial nerve and the axillary nerve. The radial nerve innervates wrist extensors and the axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor. Damage to the posterior cord commonly manifests with wrist drop due to radial nerve damage, and with loss of upper limb abduction above 15 degrees and decreased sensation over the deltoid muscle due to axillary nerve damage. This patient's presentation is not consistent with posterior cord injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Damage to the axillary nerve (C5–C6) is commonly seen in surgical neck fractures of the humerus and results in impairment of the deltoid muscle. The clinical presentation includes a loss of abduction of the upper limb above 15 degrees and decreased sensation over the deltoid muscle. This patient's presentation is not consistent with axillary nerve damage.

F) INCORRECT:

Traumatic damage to the radial nerve (C5–T1) is seen in midshaft humeral fractures or prolonged axillary compression, causing, e.g., Saturday night palsy. Clinical presentation includes wrist drop, weakened hand grip, and loss of sensation over the posterior aspect of the upper limb. This patient's presentation is not consistent with radial nerve damage.

G) CORRECT:

The musculocutaneous nerve arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus (union of C5–C7 nerve roots). Damage to this nerve can arise from upper limb compression or laceration to the lateral aspect of the arm. This patient's inability to flex the right elbow and supinate the right forearm in conjunction with a history of trauma is highly suggestive of an injury to the musculocutaneous nerve.

H) INCORRECT:

Traumatic median nerve palsy (C5–T1) most commonly occurs with supracondylar fractures of the humerus. The clinical presentation includes impaired wrist pronation and flexion, impaired lateral flexion of the index and middle finger, loss of thumb opposition (hand of benediction, ape hand deformity), and sensory loss over the index and middle finger and the radial side of the ring finger. This patient's presentation is not consistent with median nerve injury.

I) INCORRECT:

Traumatic damage to the ulnar nerve (C8–T1) is seen in fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus or the hook of the hamate. It results in impaired flexion of the ring and little finger (ulnar claw deformity) as well as loss of sensation over the little finger and the medial side of the ring finger. This patient's presentation is not consistent with ulnar nerve injury.
questions.hint: Weakness with elbow flexion and forearm supination along with decreased sensation over the anterolateral forearm is consistent with an injury to the musculocutaneous nerve.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 week after undergoing rotator cuff repair surgery. Physical examination of the right shoulder shows decreased sensation to pinprick and light touch over the lateral shoulder. There is normal passive range of motion of the shoulder, but she has difficulty externally rotating and abducting her right arm. Which of the following structures was most likely injured during the surgery?

choices.text: Upper trunk of the brachial plexus
Lower trunk of the brachial plexus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The radial nerve can be injured by compression within the axilla (e.g., due to crutches), a midshaft fracture of the humerus, or repeated pronation/supination of the forearm. In contrast to the features seen in this patient, radial nerve palsy manifests with impaired elbow, wrist, and finger extension; reduced grip strength; and sensory deficits over the posterior arm, posterior forearm, and dorsal hand.

B) INCORRECT:

Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus results in Erb palsy. Paralysis of the deltoid, supraspinatus, and infraspinatus muscles results in impaired shoulder abduction and external rotation, which are both seen in this patient. However, the biceps brachii muscle is also affected, resulting in impaired flexion and supination. Patients present with an extended, medially rotated, and pronated arm. In adults, Erb palsy typically occurs secondary to trauma (excessive traction or tear of the nerves). It occurs most often in newborns as a result of excessive lateral flexion of the head during delivery.

C) CORRECT:

Injury to the axillary nerve results in impaired abduction (from 15–100°) due to deltoid paralysis, limited external rotation due to teres minor paralysis, and sensory deficits over the skin of the lateral deltoid. Because the axillary nerve circumflexes the neck of the humerus, injury to the nerve from excessive traction or direct injury can result from rotator cuff surgery, fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus, or anterior dislocation of the humerus.

D) INCORRECT:

In adults, injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus typically occurs secondary to trauma (e.g., an attempt to grab an object to break a fall from a height) and leads to Klumpke palsy. In contrast to this patient's features, it manifests as paralysis of the intrinsic hand muscles (lumbricals, interossei, thenar eminence, and hypothenar muscles) and often forearm muscles (flexors of the wrist and fingers; sometimes also the pronators), which classically presents as “claw hand.” Klumpke palsy is uncommon in adults. It is most commonly seen in newborns following a birth trauma (i.e., hyperabduction of the arm during delivery).

E) INCORRECT:

Long thoracic nerve injury typically occurs secondary to chest wall injuries and axillary node dissection during mastectomy. Injury to this nerve results in paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle, which causes medial winging of the scapula and impaired shoulder abduction beyond 90°. Long thoracic nerve injury would not, however, account for this patient's sensory deficit over the lateral shoulder or the impaired external rotation in her arm.
questions.hint: Injury to this structure can also occur after delayed reduction of an anterior shoulder dislocation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He reports right hip pain and numbness along the right thigh. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch over a small area of the medial thigh. X-rays of the pelvis show a displaced pelvic ring fracture. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Sensory deficit of the dorsal foot

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sensory deficits of the dorsal foot can be caused by injury to the superficial peroneal branch of the common peroneal nerve, which provides sensory cutaneous innervation to the lateral lower leg and dorsal aspect of the foot. However, injury to the common peroneal nerve or its branches would not cause decreased sensation in the medial thigh.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired hip extension can occur in the setting of hip dislocation or hip arthroplasty. The muscles involved in hip extension include the gluteus maximus (innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve), and the semitendinosus and semimembranosus (both innervated by the sciatic nerve). Neither the inferior gluteal nerve nor the sciatic nerve provides sensory innervation to the medial thigh.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired dorsiflexion of the foot can be seen in common peroneal nerve injury, which typically occurs in the setting of fibular head fractures or external compression of the common peroneal nerve at the level of the fibular head. The branches of the common peroneal nerve provide sensory innervation to the first dorsal web space and the lateral lower leg and dorsal foot. Injury to this nerve would not explain the patient's decreased sensation in the medial thigh.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired extension of the knee can occur following injury to the femoral nerve, which innervates the quadriceps muscles. Although femoral nerve injury can be caused by direct trauma (e.g., fracture, compression from a hematoma) it is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's sensory deficit on the medial thigh because sensory fibers from the femoral nerve also provide cutaneous innervation to the medial lower leg and foot.

E) INCORRECT:

Absence of the cremasteric reflex is seen in patients with injury to the genitofemoral nerve, as the nerve provides motor innervation to the cremaster muscle. The genitofemoral nerve also provides sensory cutaneous innervation to the scrotum in men and to the mons pubis and labia majora in women; there are also cutaneous branches to the proximal aspect of the anteromedial thigh. This patient presents with decreased sensation to the medial thigh, which could be seen in genitofemoral nerve injury. However, pelvic ring fractures are not associated with genitofemoral nerve injuries.

F) CORRECT:

Pelvic ring fracture is a common cause of obturator nerve injury. In addition to providing sensory cutaneous innervation to a small area of the medial thigh, the obturator nerve also provides motor innervation to the hip adductor muscles in the medial compartment of the thigh. Thus, injury to the nerve can result in impaired adduction of the hip.
questions.hint: This man has a pelvic ring fracture with decreased sensation over a small area of the right medial thigh. This is consistent with an obturator nerve injury.

questions.text: Seven hours after undergoing left hip arthroplasty for chronic hip pain, a 67-year-old woman reports a prickling sensation in her left anteromedial thigh and lower leg. Neurologic examination shows left leg strength 3/5 on hip flexion and 2/5 on knee extension. Patellar reflex is decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch are decreased on the anteromedial left thigh as well as medial lower leg. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sural nerve injury is usually caused by Achilles tendon rupture, entrapment, or ganglion lipomas. The sural nerve is a purely sensory nerve, and injury to it typically manifests with decreased sensation on the posterolateral lower leg and the lateral border of the foot. It would not explain the loss of sensation on the anteromedial thigh and decreased strength in knee extension seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has evidence of femoral nerve injury, likely from prolonged compression during surgery. Injury of the femoral nerve typically results in loss of sensation in the anteromedial thigh and medial lower leg (anterior cutaneous branches), as well as decreased strength in hip flexion (iliopsoas muscle) and knee extension (quadriceps femoris muscle).

C) INCORRECT:

Fibular nerve injury is usually caused by injuries in the lower leg (e.g., fracture of the fibular head or tight-fitting casts of the lower leg). It typically presents with foot drop (weakness of foot dorsiflexors) and a loss of sensation between the first and second toe (deep peroneal nerve branch) and the back of the feet and toes (superficial peroneal nerve branch). Fibular nerve injury would not cause loss of sensation in the anteromedial thigh or the decreased knee extension seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Obturator nerve injury usually results from pelvic ring fractures or entrapment. It typically manifests with loss of sensation of the medial thigh (cutaneous branch of the obturator nerve) and decreased strength in the hip adductors. It would not explain this patient's loss of sensation in the anterior thigh or her decreased strength in knee extension.

E) INCORRECT:

S1 radiculopathy typically causes back pain that radiates down the posterior leg into the foot, with sensory loss along the lateral foot, weakness in plantar flexion and eversion, and a decreased Achilles tendon reflex. This patient's symptoms are localized to different areas and do not follow a radicular pattern.

F) INCORRECT:

L5 radiculopathy typically causes back pain that radiates down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot, with sensory loss along the lateral aspect of the lower leg and dorsum of the foot and strength deficits in foot dorsiflexion and eversion. This patient's symptoms are localized to different areas and do not follow a radicular pattern.
questions.hint: Postoperative anteromedial thigh and lower leg paresthesias with concurrent decreased patellar reflex, hip flexion, and knee extension are consistent with damage to a peripheral nerve of the anterior lower extremity.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of cramps in her left leg. Physical examination shows flexion of the left hip and increased tone in the thigh muscles. A local anesthetic block of which of the following nerves would most likely improve this patient's condition the most?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The obturator nerve (L2–L4 nerve roots) primarily innervates most of the hip adductors. Blocking it would not improve this patient's spastic hip flexion.

B) INCORRECT:

The sciatic nerve (L4–S3 nerve roots) innervates much of the lower extremity musculature directly (the adductor magnus and the hamstring muscles: biceps femoris, semitendinosus, semimembranosus) or via the common peroneal nerve and its subsequent branches. The hamstring muscles function as flexors and rotators of the knee and extensors of the hip. Blocking the sciatic nerve would decrease countering hip extension and thus exacerbate this patient's spastic hip flexion.

C) INCORRECT:

The inferior gluteal nerve (L5–S2 nerve roots) primarily innervates the gluteus maximus, which functions as a hip extensor and external rotator. Blocking it would decrease countering hip extension and thus exacerbate spastic hip flexion.

D) CORRECT:

Motor fibers of the femoral nerve (L2–L4 nerve roots) innervate the hip flexors. Selectively blocking the femoral nerve would improve hip flexor spasticity. One adverse effect, though, would be a loss of knee extension because the nerve also innervates the quadriceps femoris muscles. Since the femoral nerves also provide sensory-only fibers, another adverse effect would be a loss of feeling of her anteromedial thigh via blocking of the anterior cutaneous branches, as well as the medial lower leg and foot via a saphenous nerve deficit, respectively.

E) INCORRECT:

The superior gluteal nerve (L4–S1 nerve roots) innervates the gluteus minimus and gluteus medius, which function primarily as hip abductors, internal rotators, and external rotators of the thigh (if the hip is extended). The nerve also innervates the tensor fascia latae, which does indeed participate in hip flexion. Although blocking the superior gluteal nerve could minimally improve this patient's spastic hip flexion, blocking another nerve would improve this patient's condition more since the nerve plays a much more dominant role in hip flexion.
questions.hint: This patient is showing signs of spasticity, a common clinical feature of multiple sclerosis, of the hip flexors. The nerve that innervates these muscles originates from spinal roots L2–L4 and lies below the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 week after undergoing right-sided radical mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection for breast cancer. She says that she has been unable to comb her hair with her right hand since the surgery. Physical examination shows shoulder asymmetry. She is unable to abduct her right arm above 90 degrees. When she pushes against a wall, there is protrusion of the medial aspect of the right scapula. Injury to which of the following nerves is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Upper trunk of the brachial plexus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The upper trunk of the brachial plexus can be injured by trauma (e.g., shoulder dystocia during labor) but is at low risk for injury during axillary lymph node dissection. This nerve injury manifests with an adducted, extended, pronated, and medially rotated arm (Erb palsy). It does not cause a winged scapula.

B) INCORRECT:

The axillary nerve can be injured by trauma (e.g., anterior shoulder dislocation) or iatrogenic damage (e.g., rotator cuff surgery) but is at low risk for injury during axillary lymph node dissection. Axillary nerve injury impairs arm abduction due to paralysis of the deltoid muscle. However, it also impairs external rotation of the arm (due to paralysis of the teres minor muscle) and leads to a sensory deficit over the lower half of the deltoid region (due to injury to the superior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm). It does not cause a winged scapula.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has evidence of a long thoracic nerve injury, which is a common complication of axillary lymph node dissection. The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle; injury to the nerve typically results in medial winging of the scapula and impaired abduction of the arm beyond 90°.
Image Description:

When the patient is asked to place both palms against a wall and push, the medial border of the right scapula is abnormally prominent.

This is the characteristic appearance of scapular winging. It indicates a palsy of the serratus anterior, which is most commonly due to an injury of the long thoracic nerve.

D) INCORRECT:

The suprascapular nerve is not located in the axillary region and thus is at low risk for injury during axillary lymph node dissection. Suprascapular nerve injury causes paralysis of the infraspinatus and supraspinatus muscles, which limits adduction, abduction, and external rotation of the arm and causes shoulder instability (due to paralysis of rotator cuff muscles). It does not cause a winged scapula.

E) INCORRECT:

The thoracodorsal nerve, which innervates the latissimus dorsi and teres major muscles, can also be injured during axillary lymph node dissection. However, this nerve injury impairs shoulder retraction and adduction and internal rotation of the arm. It does not cause a winged scapula.
questions.hint: This woman has a winged scapula caused by paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of numbness in his left lower extremity. One month ago, he sustained a fracture of the neck of the left fibula during soccer practice that was treated with immobilization in a plaster cast. Physical examination of the left lower extremity is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the medial calf
Loss of sensation on the sole of the foot

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Dorsiflexion of the foot is accomplished through contraction of muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg, including the tibialis anterior (main dorsiflexor), extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, and peroneus tertius. These muscles are innervated by the deep peroneal nerve, which branches from the common peroneal nerve. Injury to the common peroneal nerve, either from the initial fibula fracture or, more likely, compression from the plaster cast, explains this patient's numbness and would result in impaired dorsiflexion and eversion on motor examination. Patients with injury to the common peroneal nerve typically present with steppage gait.

The common peroneal nerve gives rise to the superficial peroneal nerve, which innervates the dorsum of the foot, and the deep peroneal nerve, which innervates the web space between the first two toes.

B) INCORRECT:

Loss of sensation over the medial calf occurs in cases of injury to the saphenous nerve. These injuries typically arise following saphenous vein harvest for cardiac surgery or trauma to the posterior leg, not from fibular fracture.

C) INCORRECT:

Standing on one's tiptoes requires contraction of the muscles in the superficial posterior compartment of the leg, gastrocnemius, and soleus. Direct injury to these muscles or damage to the tibial nerve, which innervates these muscles, would make it impossible to stand on one's tiptoes, but this patient's history of isolated fracture of the fibular neck does not suggest these pathologies.

D) INCORRECT:

The ankle reflex is diminished in patients with spinal cord, spinal root, and peripheral nerve conditions. Specifically, processes affecting the sacral spinal cord, S1/S2 roots, or tibial nerve would be expected to manifest with reduced ankle reflexes. This patient does not have a history to suggest injury or damage to any of these structures.

E) INCORRECT:

The sole of the foot is innervated by the tibial nerve. Tibial nerve injury is typically a result of deep lacerations to the posterior leg or severely posteriorly displaced tibia fracture. Fibular fractures do not commonly affect this nerve.

F) INCORRECT:

An inability to invert the foot would be the result of an injury affecting the tibialis posterior muscle, which is innervated by the tibial nerve. This patient has no history to suggest injury to this nerve (e.g., deep laceration to the posterior leg).
questions.hint: The common peroneal nerve runs in close proximity to the lateral aspect of the fibular head, which makes it susceptible to damage or compression due to fracture of the fibular neck, tight casts, crossing of the legs, or protracted squatting.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and weakness in her right forearm and hand for several months. Two years ago, she sustained a fracture of her ulnar shaft with dislocation of the radial head that was treated surgically. Physical examination shows mild tenderness a few centimeters distal to the lateral epicondyle. She has marked weakness when attempting to extend her right middle finger. There is radial deviation on extension of the wrist. Sensation is not impaired. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Injuries to the ulnar nerve can manifest in a number of ways depending on the location of the lesion. The vast majority of injuries, however, include sensory defects in the small and ring fingers, as well as weakness in the intrinsic hand muscles, neither of which are seen in this patient. Additionally, patients with ulnar nerve dysfunction are unable to cross their fingers and may have an ulnar claw sign on examination.

B) INCORRECT:

The anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) is a motor branch of the median nerve. Damage to it would not result in changes in cutaneous sensation, which is consistent with this patient's symptoms. However, weakness with finger extension would not be expected in an injury to this nerve, either. The classic physical examination finding in patients with AIN injuries is an inability to make the “A-OK” sign with the thumb and index finger, although injury to this branch alone is rare.

C) INCORRECT:

The superficial radial nerve is a distal branch of the radial nerve. It is a purely sensory nerve and provides cutaneous innervation to the radial half of the dorsal hand, the thumb, the index finger, and the radial half of the dorsal long finger (except for the tips of the fingers, which are innervated by the median nerve). However, this patient has no cutaneous sensory symptoms. Furthermore, injury to this nerve would not account for her motor changes.

D) CORRECT:

The posterior interosseous nerve is a motor nerve that branches off from the radial nerve in close proximity to the radial head, which makes it susceptible to injury due to radial head dislocation or subluxation. Occasionally, posterior interosseous neuropathy can develop years after a fracture of the forearm or elbow. Compression of this nerve frequently impairs extension of the fingers (more than the wrist) because function of the extensor carpi radialis longus, which is innervated directly by the radial nerve, is preserved. The unopposed action of this muscle further explains the radial deviation seen on examination. Finally, this patient's normal sensory examination is one of the hallmarks of posterior interosseous neuropathy because this nerve does not provide cutaneous innervation.

The posterior interosseous nerve can also be compressed within the radial tunnel (radial tunnel syndrome).

E) INCORRECT:

The musculocutaneous nerve is responsible for elbow flexion, forearm supination, and sensation over the lateral, volar forearm. None of these functions are affected in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's weakness in her wrist extensor muscles with intact cutaneous sensation suggests a pure motor neuropathy that is sometimes associated with dislocation of the radial head.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 2 months after undergoing a total hip replacement surgery. She reports that she has persistent difficulty in walking since the surgery despite regular physiotherapy. Examination of her gait shows sagging of the left pelvis when her right leg is weight-bearing. Which of the following nerves is most likely to have been injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The left superior gluteal nerve innervates the left gluteus medius and minimus, which are responsible for abducting the left hip. Neurological weakness of these muscles would lead to a positive Trendelenburg sign or downward tilting of the pelvis toward the right side when the patient stands on her left leg.

B) INCORRECT:

The right femoral nerve innervates the right quadriceps, sartorius, pectineus, and iliopsoas, which control knee extension and thigh flexion. Femoral nerve injury would cause knee buckling (from quadriceps weakness), difficulty lifting up the thigh (problem climbing stairs), and dragging of the leg (from iliopsoas weakness); it would not cause a positive Trendelenburg sign. Sensory loss would also be seen over the medial and anterior thigh as well the medial calf, which is not present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The right inferior gluteal nerve innervates the right gluteus maximus muscle. As this muscle is the primary right thigh extensor, inferior gluteal nerve damage would lead to impairment of this function. Although rare, injuries to this nerve may occur due to misdirected intramuscular injections and operations (e.g., posterior approach to hip arthroplasty).

D) INCORRECT:

The left inferior gluteal nerve innervates the left gluteus maximus muscle. As this muscle is the primary left thigh extensor, inferior gluteal nerve damage would lead to impairment of this function. This nerve is rarely injured, but possible reasons are misdirected intramuscular injections and operations (e.g. posterior approach to hip arthroplasty).

E) INCORRECT:

The left femoral nerve innervates the left quadriceps, sartorius, pectineus, and iliopsoas, which control knee extension and thigh flexion. Femoral nerve injury would cause knee buckling (from quadriceps weakness), difficulty lifting up the thigh (problem climbing stairs), and dragging of the leg (from iliopsoas weakness), it would not cause a positive Trendelenburg sign. Sensory loss would also be seen over the medial and anterior thigh as well the medial calf, which is not present in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

The right obturator nerve innervates the right obturator externus, pectineus, gracilis, and adductors magnus, longus and brevis. Damage to the obturator nerve results in weakness of adduction, external rotation of the thigh, and a tendency for the thigh to abnormally abduct while walking; it would not cause a positive Trendelenburg sign. Damage to this nerve would also cause sensory loss in the mid and lower thirds of the right medial thigh, which is not present in this patient.

G) CORRECT:

The right superior gluteal nerve innervates the right gluteus medius and minimus, which are responsible for abducting the right hip. Damage of the right superior gluteal nerve results in lowering of the left hip while standing on the right foot (positive Trendelenburg sign). This patient's symptoms suggest that she suffered damage to the right superior gluteal nerve during total hip replacement surgery.
Image Description:

The Trendelenburg sign indicates insufficiency of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. It is tested for as follows:
(1) The pelvic level is assessed by comparing the height of both iliac crests.
(2) The patient is asked to stand on one leg, with the examiner continuously observing the level of the pelvis and the patient's posture. Normally, the pelvis is stabilized by the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which prevent a pelvic drop to the opposite side.
(3) In the case of muscle insufficiency, the pelvis drops towards the unimpaired, unsupported side (free leg), which is known as the Trendelenburg sign.
(4) Tilting of the torso toward the contralateral side compensates for the pelvic drop on the unimpaired side, which is known as Duchenne sign. Because the Duchenne sign may mask the Trendelenburg sign, it is important to always inspect the patient's overall posture.

H) INCORRECT:

The left obturator nerve innervates the left obturator externus, pectineus, gracilis, and adductors magnus, longus, and brevis. Damage to the obturator nerve results in weakness of adduction, external rotation of the thigh, and a tendency for the thigh to abnormally abduct while walking; it would not cause a positive Trendelenburg sign. Damage to this nerve would also cause sensory loss in the mid and lower thirds of the left medial thigh, which is not present in this patient.
questions.hint: Examination in this patient shows a positive Trendelenburg sign, which is caused by weakness of the hip abductors (i.e., the gluteus medius and minimus).

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent tingling of his hand. He is an avid cyclist and has recently started training for a cycle marathon. Physical examination shows decreased grip strength in the right hand and wasting of the hypothenar eminence. On asking the patient to grasp a piece of paper between his right thumb and right index finger in the first web space, there is hyperflexion of the right thumb interphalangeal joint. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Loss of sensation over dorsal aspect of 1st web space
Inability to flex the index finger at the interphalangeal joints
Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the medial half of the hand
Inability to extend the ring finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint
Inability to extend the little finger at the proximal interphalangeal joints

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sensation in the dorsal web space between the thumb and index finger is often examined to assess intact radial nerve sensation. It would not be affected by this patient's ulnar nerve compression.

B) INCORRECT:

Flexion of the index finger at either the proximal or distal interphalangeal joints requires the action of the flexor digitorum superficialis (proximal joint) or flexor digitorum profundus (proximal and distal joints). The flexor digitorum superficialis and the lateral aspect of the flexor digitorium profundus (which flexes the index and middle finger) are innervated by the median nerve and would be unaffected by this patient's ulnar nerve compression.

C) INCORRECT:

The dorsum of the medial half of the hand (ring and small fingers) is innervated by the dorsal cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve, which arises in the forearm proximal to the passage of the ulnar nerve through Guyon canal. As this patient exhibits nerve compression at the level of Guyon canal, the sensory innervation to the medial half of the dorsum of the hand will remain intact.

D) INCORRECT:

Extension of the ring finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint is mediated by the action of the extensor digitorum muscle, which is innervated by the radial nerve. The function of this muscle would not be affected by ulnar nerve compression.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's physical examination is suggestive of long-term ulnar nerve compression at the level of Guyon canal (Guyon canal syndrome), which is common in avid cyclists due to long-term pressure of the wrist against bike handlebars. This compression disrupts innervation to the ulnar innervated intrinsic hand muscles, including the lumbricals, which are responsible for little finger extension at the proximal interphalangeal joint. Additional physical exam findings typically seen in this syndrome include numbness of the palmar surface of the small and ring fingers.

While splinting, cortisone injections, and NSAIDs may improve this patient's complaints, surgical release of the volar carpal ligament is required in refractory cases.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function
questions.hint: A positive Froment sign (hyperflexion of the thumb due to paralysis of the adductor pollicis and unopposed action of flexor pollicis longus) and wasting of the hypothenar eminence are suggestive of ulnar nerve entrapment.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of a tingling sensation in his right forearm. He reports that his symptoms started after he lifted heavy weights at the gym. Physical examination shows loss of sensation on the lateral side of the right forearm. Sensation over the thumb is intact. Range of motion of the neck is normal. His symptoms do not worsen with axial compression or distraction of the neck. Further examination of this patient is most likely to show weakness of which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Shoulder abduction is predominantly controlled by the deltoid muscle, which is innervated by the axillary nerve. The axillary nerve also controls sensation over the distal half of the deltoid region. Given this patient's sensory changes over the lateral forearm, it is unlikely that he has an axillary nerve injury.

B) CORRECT:

Elbow flexion is controlled by the biceps brachii and brachialis muscles, which are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. Musculocutaneous nerve injury can result from lifting heavy weights as seen in this case. This injury also impairs forearm supination and the biceps tendon reflex. The normal range of motion in the neck and negative Spurling sign indicate that this patient has a peripheral nerve lesion.

Some symptoms of musculocutaneous nerve injury may be masked by the fact that the supinator muscle (innervated by the radial nerve) can at least partially compensate for the supination deficit; in addition, the brachioradialis muscle (also innervated by the radial nerve) is an elbow flexor.

C) INCORRECT:

Forearm pronation is controlled by the pronator teres and pronator quadratus muscles, which are innervated by the median nerve. The median nerve also controls sensation on the lateral aspect of the palm, including the thumb. Given this patient's symptoms of primarily lateral forearm sensory loss without involvement of the thumb or hand, it is unlikely that he has a median nerve injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Index finger flexion is controlled by the median nerve. Median nerve injury leads to sensory loss over the lateral aspect of the palm, including the thumb. Though the median nerve controls many of the muscles of the forearm, it does not control sensation of the forearm. Given this patient's symptoms of primarily lateral forearm sensory loss without involvement of the thumb or hand, it is unlikely that he has a median nerve injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Wrist extension is controlled by the radial nerve, which also controls sensation over the posterior surface of the forearm extending to the dorsolateral hand. Since this patient's sensory loss is over the lateral portion of the forearm without any hand involvement, it is unlikely that he has a radial nerve injury.

F) INCORRECT:

The pinch grip is controlled by the anterior interosseous nerve, a purely motor branch of the median nerve. Distal lesions can lead to loss of flexion in the distal joints of the thumb and index finger due to impaired innervation of the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus muscles. Because this patient has sensory loss over the lateral forearm without hand involvement, it is unlikely that he has a median nerve injury.
Image Description:

The anterior interosseous nerve is a pure motor branch of the median nerve. It supplies the flexor pollicis longus, the radial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (and the pronator quadratus).

Pinch sign: an inability to flex the DIP of the index finger and IP joint of the thumb when asked to make an “OK” sign that is caused by a lesion or entrapment of the anterior interosseous nerve
questions.hint: The lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, which innervates the lateral surface of the forearm, is a branch of the musculocutaneous nerve.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with osteoarthritis of the knee comes to the physician for evaluation of weakness in his foot. Physical examination shows a swelling in the popliteal fossa. There is marked weakness when attempting to invert his right foot. He is unable to curl his toes. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show decreased sensation over which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The second dorsal web space, the anterolateral inferior third of the leg, and most of the foot dorsum (except for the first web space) receive sensory innervation from the superficial peroneal nerve. The motor portion of this nerve supplies the lateral compartment of the leg, allowing for foot eversion. Injury to the superficial peroneal nerve occurs secondary to entrapment at the lateral ankle or via fibular fracture, not as a result of the popliteal swelling seen in this patient. Likewise, deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with a superficial peroneal nerve injury.

B) CORRECT:

The sole of the foot, lateral foot, and posterolateral leg are innervated by sensory branches of the tibial nerve (nerve stem from L4–S3). The posterior compartment of the leg, responsible for foot inversion and plantarflexion of the toes and ankle, is innervated by motor branches of the tibial nerve. This patient's neurapraxia of the tibial nerve secondary to popliteal swelling would diminish the sensory and motor functions of these regions.

C) INCORRECT:

The sensory branch of the deep peroneal nerve provides sensation to the first web space, while the motor portion supplies the anterior compartment of the leg, which is responsible for foot and toe dorsiflexion. Injury is usually the result of anterior compartment compression or ski boot syndrome, not the popliteal swelling seen in this patient. Likewise, deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with deep peroneal nerve injury.

D) INCORRECT:

The medial plantar arch and the medial leg and foot are innervated by the saphenous nerve, which has a purely cutaneous sensory function. Therefore, this patient's motor deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with saphenous nerve injury. The saphenous nerve would also not be injured by popliteal swelling.

E) INCORRECT:

The lateral border of the foot is innervated by the sural nerve, which provides a purely cutaneous sensory function to the inferior portion of the posterolateral leg. Injury to the sural nerve is often secondary to calcaneal fracture or trauma, not popliteal swelling as this patient has. Likewise, deficits of foot inversion and toe plantar flexion do not correlate with sural nerve injury.
questions.hint: Swelling of the popliteal fossa can lead to compression of the inlying structures, including the tibial nerve. Compression of the tibial nerve can result in neurapraxia, causing marked motor weakness of foot inversion and toe plantarflexion, as well as sensory deficits in the tibial nerve distribution.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of an irregular gait 3 days after receiving age-appropriate vaccinations. Examination of the lower extremities shows no redness or swelling. When the child stands on his right leg, his left leg drops and his pelvis tilts towards the left. Sensation to light touch is normal in both legs. This patient's symptoms are most likely due to the injection of the vaccine into which of the following locations?

choices.text: Superomedial quadrant of the left buttock
Inferolateral quadrant of the right buttock
Inferomedial quadrant of the right buttock
Inferomedial quadrant of the left buttock
Superomedial quadrant of the right buttock
Inferolateral quadrant of the left buttock

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The left superior gluteal nerve lies in this region. Injury to this nerve would cause a positive Trendelenburg sign and a gait abnormality. However, with an injury to the left superior gluteal nerve, a pelvic tilt would not occur when the patient stands on his right leg.
Image Description:

The nerves of the lower extremity arise from the lumbar and sacral plexuses.
The sciatic nerve (L4–S3), inferior gluteal nerve, posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh, and pudendal nerve exit the pelvis dorsally through the greater sciatic foramen, inferior to the piriformis muscle. The superior gluteal nerve is the only nerve that exits the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle.
The sciatic nerve branches at the popliteal fossa into the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve.

The cutaneous nerves penetrate through the deep fascia and enter the subcutaneous plane to supply their dermatomes.
The sural nerve is a cutaneous nerve formed by the union of the medial sural cutaneous nerve (originating from the tibial nerve) and the lateral sural cutaneous nerve (originating from the common peroneal nerve).
The medial and lateral plantar nerves are the cutaneous terminal branches of the tibial nerve.

B) INCORRECT:

The right sciatic nerve courses through this region. Sciatic nerve injury can cause an abnormal gait (high-stepping gait), but features such as foot drop, weakened knee flexion, and sensory loss over the foot and lateral surface of the lower leg would also be present ipsilaterally. Lateral tilting of the pelvis would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

The right sciatic nerve and right inferior gluteal nerve lie in this region. While sciatic nerve injury can cause an abnormal gait (high-stepping gait), features such as foot drop, weakened knee flexion, and sensory loss over the foot and lateral surface of the lower leg would also be present ipsilaterally. Inferior gluteal nerve injury can cause an abnormal gait (backward lurching gait), but the patient would also have impaired hip extension, and a forward pelvic tilt while standing on the affected side. Lateral tilting of the pelvis would not be expected with an isolated injury to either of these nerves.

D) INCORRECT:

The left sciatic nerve and left inferior gluteal nerve lie in this region. While sciatic nerve injury can cause an abnormal gait (high-stepping gait), features such as foot drop, weakened knee flexion, and sensory loss over the foot and lateral surface of the lower leg would also be present ipsilaterally. Inferior gluteal nerve injury can cause an abnormal gait (backward lurching gait), but the patient would also have impaired hip extension and a forward pelvic tilt while standing on the affected side. Lateral tilting of the pelvis would not be expected with an isolated injury to either of these nerves.

E) CORRECT:

The superior gluteal nerve lies in this region and innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fascia latae, which prevent the pelvis from tilting to the contralateral side. Injury to the right superior gluteal nerve would, therefore, cause the pelvis to tilt towards the left side when bearing weight on the right leg (positive Trendelenburg sign). In order to compensate for this pelvic tilt, the patient would tilt the trunk to the right. Intramuscular injections are typically given in the superolateral quadrant of the buttock to avoid nerve injury.
Image Description:

The Trendelenburg sign indicates insufficiency of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. It is tested for as follows:
(1) The pelvic level is assessed by comparing the height of both iliac crests.
(2) The patient is asked to stand on one leg, with the examiner continuously observing the level of the pelvis and the patient's posture. Normally, the pelvis is stabilized by the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which prevent a pelvic drop to the opposite side.
(3) In the case of muscle insufficiency, the pelvis drops towards the unimpaired, unsupported side (free leg), which is known as the Trendelenburg sign.
(4) Tilting of the torso toward the contralateral side compensates for the pelvic drop on the unimpaired side, which is known as Duchenne sign. Because the Duchenne sign may mask the Trendelenburg sign, it is important to always inspect the patient's overall posture.

F) INCORRECT:

The left sciatic nerve courses through this region. Sciatic nerve injury can cause an abnormal gait (high-stepping gait), but features such as foot drop, weakened knee flexion, and sensory loss over the foot and lateral surface of the lower leg would also be present ipsilaterally. Lateral tilting of the pelvis would not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's abnormal gait is most likely caused by weakness of hip abductors due to iatrogenic nerve injury.

questions.text: A 3629-g (8-lb) newborn is examined shortly after spontaneous vaginal delivery. She was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother is concerned because she is not moving her left arm as much as her right arm. Physical examination shows her left arm to be adducted and internally rotated, with the forearm extended and pronated, and the wrist flexed. The Moro reflex is present on the right side but absent on the left side. Which of the following brachial plexus structures is most likely injured in this infant?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Erb palsy is due to injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, which contributes to the motor and sensory function of the suprascapular nerve, musculocutaneous nerve, and axillary nerve. Erb palsy most commonly occurs secondary to shoulder dystocia or other birth trauma but can arise in adults as a result of neck and/or upper arm trauma.

B) INCORRECT:

Injury to the long thoracic nerve, which receives nerve fibers from the C5–C7 nerve roots, classically manifests with impaired abduction of the arm above 90° and winging of the scapula (due to innervation of the serratus anterior muscle). An isolated long thoracic nerve injury due to birth trauma would be very unusual. This patient's examination findings are consistent with injury to a different structure.

C) INCORRECT:

Injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus results in Klumpke palsy. Klumpke palsy commonly occurs secondary to birth trauma. It typically manifests as paralysis of the intrinsic hand muscles and forearm flexors, resulting in the characteristic “claw hand” and absent grasp reflex. Horner syndrome may also be present. This patient's “waiter's tip” position is not consistent with a lower trunk injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Injury to the axillary nerve would result in the inability to externally rotate and abduct the arm above 15°. An isolated axillary nerve injury would not explain this patient's other findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Injury to the posterior cord classically results in wrist drop (loss of radial nerve innervation of forearm extensors) and inability to externally rotate or abduct the arm (loss of axillary nerve innervation of deltoid muscle). Isolated damage to the posterior cord during birth is extremely rare and would not be consistent with the examination findings in this patient.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP joints

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2nd and 3rd fingers. The 1st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumb

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function
questions.hint: This infant's left arm is in a “waiter's tip” position, which suggests impaired shoulder abduction and lateral rotation, as well as impaired elbow flexion and forearm supination. This injury is common in neonates who require lateral neck traction during vaginal delivery and is associated with shoulder dystocia.

questions.text: An investigator is studying cellular repair mechanisms in various tissues. One of the samples being reviewed is from the anterior horn of the spinal cord of a patient who was involved in a snowboard accident. Pathologic examination of the biopsy specimen shows dispersion of the Nissl bodies, swelling of the neuronal body, and a displacement of the nucleus to the periphery in numerous cells. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the observed findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neurodegenerative changes occur in response to the loss of function and structure of neurons in neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Parkinson disease, Alzheimer disease, Huntington disease). These changes manifest in many different ways depending on the neurodegenerative diseases. Mechanisms include genetic mutations, protein misfolding, intracellular defects (e.g., of protein degradation pathways, mitochondria, membrane, DNA, or axons), defective programmed cell death, and transglutaminases. However, the described findings in this question suggest another etiology.

B) INCORRECT:
