Early ischemic damages manifest with retraction of the cellular outlines, pyknosis, disappearance of the Nissl bodies, and eosinophilic condensation of the cytoplasm, unlike the biopsy findings here.

C) INCORRECT:

Wallerian degeneration is a process that occurs in response to a proximal axonal or neuronal cell body injury. It is characterized by degeneration of the distal segment of the transected nerve fiber and axonal retraction proximally but does not cause the changes described in the biopsy findings here.

D) CORRECT:

Central chromatolysis is a reaction of a neuronal cell body (also known as the soma) in response to an axonal injury. It is characterized by swelling of the neuronal body, dispersion of the Nissl bodies, and displacement of the nucleus to the periphery. These changes reflect an increase in protein synthesis aimed at restoring the integrity of the damaged axon. Chromatolysis occurs concurrently with Wallerian degeneration.

E) INCORRECT:

Reactive astrogliosis is a nonspecific reactive change in response to damage in the central nervous system. Proliferation of various glial cell lineages, including astrocytes, microglia, and oligodendrocytes, can be seen. The hypothesized function of this response is to control oxidative damage to the remaining neurons, quickly reestablish the blood-brain barrier, and to lay down acute scar tissue. The changes observed in this tissue sample are within neurons, not glial cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Neuronal aging is characterized by lipofuscin deposition in the neuronal cell body. The clinical consequences of this histologic finding are not known.
questions.hint: This reaction is most commonly seen in neurons following injury to their axons.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after being bitten by a rattlesnake. He was hiking in the Arizona desert when he accidentally stepped on the snake and it bit his right leg. His pulse is 135/min and blood pressure is 104/81 mm Hg. Examination shows right lower leg swelling, ecchymosis, and blistering. Right ankle dorsiflexion elicits severe pain. A manometer inserted in the lateral compartment of the lower leg shows an intracompartmental pressure of 67 mm Hg. In addition to administration of the antivenom, the patient undergoes fasciotomy. Two weeks later, he reports difficulty with walking. Neurologic examination shows a loss of sensation over the lower part of the lateral side of the right leg and the dorsum of the right foot. Right foot eversion is 1/5. There is no weakness upon dorsiflexion. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A tibial nerve injury causes impaired motor function of the flexor muscles of the foot, leading to an inability to invert the foot or walk on the toes or balls of the foot, none of which is seen here. Patients will also experience sensory loss on the sole of the foot, not the dorsum of the foot. Moreover, injury during a lateral fasciotomy is unlikely because the tibial nerve is located in the deep posterior compartment of the leg.

B) INCORRECT:

The sural nerve is a purely sensory branch of the tibial nerve, which runs superficially to the superficial posterior compartment of the leg. Injury to this nerve causes impaired sensation on the posterolateral side of the lower leg, ankle, heel, and foot, but not on the anterolateral side of the leg and dorsum of the foot. Moreover, patients will not present with motor findings. Finally, injury to this nerve during lateral fasciotomy is unlikely given its location on the posterior aspect of the leg.

C) INCORRECT:

A deep peroneal nerve injury causes impaired motor function of the foot and toe extensors as well as decreased sensation in the webspace between the hallux and second digit of the foot. Patients will present with difficulties with dorsiflexion and eversion that lead to the characteristic steppage gait. This patient does not have any weakness in dorsiflexion. Moreover, injury during a lateral fasciotomy is unlikely because the deep peroneal nerve is located in the anterior compartment of the leg.

D) CORRECT:

The superficial peroneal nerve supplies motor innervation to the lateral compartment of the leg, the main functions of which are foot eversion and plantar flexion. Injury to this nerve compromises foot eversion but does not affect dorsiflexion, which is produced by the anterior compartment of the leg that is innervated by the deep peroneal nerve. The superficial peroneal nerve also supplies sensory innervation to the distal part of the anterolateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot (except for the first web space); injury to this nerve thus results in loss of sensation in this area.

This patient originally presented with features of compartment syndrome (severe leg swelling and pain, increased compartment pressure) and underwent emergency fasciotomy, which is associated with a risk of nerve injury. Risk factors for compartment syndrome include animal venoms (e.g., rattlesnake bites), circumferential burns, long bone fractures, and crush injuries.
Image Description:

Transverse section of the right leg (caudal view)

The interosseous membrane and deep fascial septa divide the leg into three compartments:
1. Anterior (extensor) compartment: bound by the tibia and the anterior intermuscular septum (junction of blue and purple compartments)
2. Lateral (fibular) compartment: bound by the anterior and posterior intermuscular septum (junction of purple and green compartments)
3. Posterior (flexor) compartment, which is further divided into:
- Deep posterior compartment: bound by the interosseous membrane anteriorly (junction of blue and orange compartments) and the transverse intermuscular septum posteriorly (junction of orange and green)
- Superficial posterior compartment: posterior to the transverse intermuscular septum

E) INCORRECT:

The saphenous nerve is a purely sensory nerve that innervates the medial side of the leg, knee, and foot. Fasciotomy of the lateral compartment of the leg would not affect the saphenous nerve because it travels medially down the leg to the foot. Additionally, injury to the saphenous nerve would not present with motor findings.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are most likely due to intraoperative injury of the nerve that innervates the fibularis longus and fibularis brevis muscles.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 1 day
Sex Assigned at Birth: F 
Race/Ethnicity: Hispanic 
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: brought in by her parents because “her arm looks funny”
History of Present Illness:

mother had no prenatal care
labor was spontaneous with rupture of membranes yielding fluid with dark green streaks
the infant was delivered vaginally 1 day ago at home at approximately 39 weeks' gestation
the delivery was complicated by shoulder dystocia, which was managed with suprapubic pressure and the McRoberts maneuver 
father reports that the infant's right arm “just hangs by the side” and that she never bends her right elbow

the infant is breastfeeding, stooling, and voiding without complication

Past Medical History: 
unremarkable
Family History:

mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus

Medications:
none
Immunizations:
has not received any routine vaccinations 
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Psychosocial History:

the infant lives with her mother, father, and paternal grandmother
no one in the residence smokes

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
Head circumference


37.1°C(98.8°F)
154/min
45/min
87/49 mm Hg
99%

50 cm(20 in)69th percentile

4400 g(9 lb 11 oz)99th percentile


35 cm (13.8 in)82nd percentile



Appearance: well-appearing; crying during the examination 
HEENT: red reflex is seen bilaterally; there is a fluctuant area over the left parietal bone that crosses suture lines
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm; normal S1 and S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: no tenderness, masses, or hepatosplenomegaly; bowel sounds normal; umbilical stump is intact and clamped
Extremities: hips are stable bilaterally
Musculoskeletal: clavicles are intact bilaterally; the right upper extremity hangs limply from the shoulder in full extension, adduction, and fixed internal rotation; the hand is pronated, and the wrist and fingers are flexed
Skin: dry, warm; no jaundice
Neurologic: normal suck and grasp reflexes; the Moro reflex is normal in the left upper extremity and absent in the right upper extremity; deep tendon reflexes are absent in the right biceps


Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's upper extremity symptoms?

choices.text: Damage to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus
Damage to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus
Fibrosis and contracture of the sternocleidomastoid muscle

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Injury to the median nerve can manifest with motor deficits (e.g., of thumb opposition and abduction, wrist pronation and flexion, index and middle finger flexion) and sensory deficits (e.g., on the thumb, index, middle, and radial side of the ring finger) that correlate to the location of injury (e.g., proximal or distal to the elbow or within the wrist). Injury to the median nerve is exceptionally rare among neonates. Moreover, this patient's neurologic examination findings are not consistent with median nerve palsy.
Image Description:

AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

B) INCORRECT:

Clavicular fractures are the most commonly reported fractures in neonates during vaginal or cesarean delivery. Nondisplaced fractures are typically asymptomatic and are detected after a callus develops several weeks after delivery. Displaced fractures can manifest with swelling, crepitus, pseudoparalysis, tenderness upon palpation, and pain with passive motion of the shoulder. Clavicular fractures are not associated with peripheral nerve palsies. Moreover, this neonate has a normal clavicular examination.
Image Description:

X-ray upper chest (AP view) of a newborn

A complete fracture of the mid-third of the left clavicle shows overriding of the fragments (green overlay).

Fractures of the clavicle are the most common birth trauma and may be complete or incomplete. Major causes include extended arms in breech presentation deliveries and shoulder dystocia in vertex presentation deliveries.

1: left first rib; white outlines: clavicle

C) CORRECT:

Damage to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus results in Erb palsy, the most common neonatal brachial plexus palsy. The most commonly involved nerve roots are C5 and C6, which results in adduction and internal rotation of the arm and extension and pronation of the forearm. Less commonly, the C7 nerve root is also involved, which results in flexion of the wrist and fingers, as seen in this patient. Erb palsy is typically caused by excessive lateral traction on the fetal head during complex obstetric maneuvers, which are often required to deliver fetuses with macrosomia (which, in this patient, was most likely caused by maternal diabetes). Most cases of Erb palsy resolve spontaneously within the first year of life with conservative management (e.g., immobilization, splinting, and physical therapy); surgical intervention is considered when functional impairment does not improve.

This neonate also has caput succedaneum, an area of fluctuance on the head that crosses suture lines, as a result of prolonged engagement of the fetal head during delivery.

D) INCORRECT:

Damage of the lower trunk (C8–T1) of the brachial plexus results in Klumpke palsy, a neonatal brachial plexus palsy that is most commonly caused by hyperabduction (excessive upward traction) of the arm during delivery, which can occur during complex obstetric maneuvers. Klumpke palsy classically manifests with isolated paralysis of the hand; this neonate, who has normal grasp reflexes, is unlikely to have this condition. Additional manifestations of Klumpke palsy include Horner syndrome (due to the approximation of the sympathetic chain to the T1 nerve root) and the development of muscular atrophy of the intrinsic hand muscles, which can lead to a “claw hand” deformity.

E) INCORRECT:

Perinatal asphyxia (e.g., due to maternal hypotension, placental insufficiency, knotting of the umbilical cord) is a life-threatening condition that can result in multiorgan failure, cerebral injury, and, in severe cases, neonatal encephalopathy and death. Neonates who are successfully stabilized may develop lethargy, poor feeding, hypotonia, apnea, and seizures; they do not typically have an isolated peripheral nerve palsy. Long-term complications of perinatal asphyxia include intellectual disability, developmental delay, and cerebral palsy.

F) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis and contracture of the sternocleidomastoid muscle can cause congenital torticollis (infant torticollis), which is typically associated with intrauterine constraint (e.g., due to oligohydramnios, multiple gestations, macrosomia), decreased fetal movement, breech presentation, and assisted vaginal delivery. It does not cause peripheral nerve palsies. Congenital torticollis is characterized by persistent tilting of the head to one side, with the chin rotated toward the opposite side. Neonates typically have restricted range of motion and can develop thickening of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. None of these manifestations are seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Congenital muscular torticollis (CMT) is caused by fibrosis and/or contraction of a sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle, resulting in neck flexion toward the affected SCM and chin rotation toward the opposite side. Physical examination typically shows limited passive range of motion (limited rotation and flexion of the neck). If untreated, CMT can result in craniofacial asymmetry.

G) INCORRECT:

Meconium aspiration syndrome occurs when a neonate aspirates meconium in the amniotic fluid during or shortly after delivery. Meconium is typically sterile, but exposure to the lung tissue causes the release of inflammatory and vasoactive substances, which can lead to marked respiratory distress. Although fluid with dark green streaks was present during the delivery of this neonate, she does not have manifestations of meconium aspiration syndrome, which include tachypnea, cyanosis, nasal flaring, grunting, accessory muscle use, and intercostal retractions. Moreover, this condition does not cause peripheral nerve palsies.
questions.hint: This patient has peripheral nerve palsy characterized by extension, adduction, and internal rotation of the arm, in combination with pronation of the hand and flexion of the wrist and fingers. These findings are commonly referred to as the waiter's tip posture.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Four months ago, she underwent posterior arthrodesis for thoracolumbar scoliosis. She has recovered well from the surgery but noticed difficulties combing her hair with her right hand. A photograph of the patient's back is shown. The nerve that was most likely injured in the surgery originates from which of the following spinal roots?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The lower trunk of the brachial plexus and the ulnar nerve receive nerve fibers from C8–T1 spinal roots. In surgeries that require the patient to be in a prone position (e.g., spinal surgery), improper positioning of the arms can injure the lower trunk (due to arm hyperabduction) or the ulnar nerve (due to pressure on the cubital tunnel). However, lower brachial plexus palsy (Klumpke palsy) would manifest with weakness of all the intrinsic muscles of the hand and sensory deficits on the medial side of the corresponding upper limb. Ulnar nerve injury results in weakness of the fourth and fifth lumbricals and sensory deficits in the fourth and fifth digit. Scapular winging would not be expected in either condition.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

B) INCORRECT:

The thoracodorsal nerve receives nerve fibers from the C6–C8 spinal roots. It lies along the posterior axillary wall, making it vulnerable to injury during axillary lymph node dissection. Injury to this nerve causes weakness of the latissimus dorsi and teres major and manifests with impaired internal rotation and adduction of the arm. Scapular winging or difficulty with combing hair would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

The ansa cervicalis receives nerve fibers from C1–C3 spinal roots. It lies in the carotid triangle of the neck and primarily innervates the infrahyoid muscles. Damage to the ansa cervicalis can occur during neck dissection or trauma to the cervical spine and results in a change in voice and swallowing difficulties. Scapular winging or difficulty with combing hair would not be expected.
Image Description:

Lateral view of the right cervical plexus

The hypoglossal and accessory nerve (gray) are not part of the cervical plexus and are provided here as anatomical landmarks only.

The branches of the cervical plexus (gray) make up the ansa cervicalis and innervate the infrahyoid muscles.

D) INCORRECT:

The phrenic nerve arises from the C3–C5 spinal roots and innervates the diaphragm and pericardium. It can be injured during anterior scalenectomy, open heart or thoracoscopic mediastinal surgery, pulmonary vein radiofrequency ablation, and IVC clamping during hepatectomy or liver transplantation. Phrenic nerve injury manifests with dyspnea and, in the case of unilateral palsy, asymmetric chest movement. Scapular winging or difficulty with combing hair would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Each thoracic intercostal nerve arises from the corresponding spinal root (e.g., second intercostal nerve from T2 spinal root) and innervates the corresponding intercostal muscle. The second to fifth intercostal nerves also innervate the serratus posterior superior muscle. Intercostal nerve injury typically occurs during the placement of a chest drain or thoracotomy. However, the muscles innervated by these nerves are accessory respiratory muscles, and their paralysis is clinically insignificant as long as the diaphragm functions. Neuralgic pain is the only significant symptom following intercostal nerve injury.
Image Description:

Illustration of the intercostal artery, vein, and nerve (forming the intercostal neurovascular bundle) within the costal groove

As the pathway of these structures follows the inferior edge of the ribs, medical interventions (e.g., chest tube insertion) are always performed along the superior edge of the rib. The order of the structures of the neurovascular bundle can be remembered using the acronym “VAN”: the intercostal vein (V) is superior, the artery (A) is in the middle, and the nerve (N) is inferior.

F) CORRECT:

The long thoracic nerve originates directly from the C5–C7 anterior spinal roots, enters the axillary cavity, and descends together with the lateral thoracic artery along the lateral surface of the thoracic cage. In surgeries that require the patient to be in a prone position (e.g., spinal surgery), improper positioning of the arms can compress and injure this nerve. This injury leads to paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle, which manifests with medial winging of the scapula and weakened abduction of the shoulder above 90° (manifesting, e.g., during hair combing), as seen here. Further common causes of long thoracic nerve injury include invasive procedures (e.g., axillary lymph node dissection), direct trauma to the shoulder, and prolonged nerve compression (e.g., carrying a heavy backpack).

The musculocutaneous nerve also receives nerve fibers from C5–C7 spinal roots, but it arises as a branch of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus rather than directly from the spinal roots. Injury to the musculocutaneous nerve (e.g., a gunshot wound in the arm) manifests with loss of sensation over the lateral forearm and impaired flexion and supination of the forearm.
questions.hint: The image shows winging of the scapula, which is characteristic of long thoracic nerve injury.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room because of pain in her right shoulder after falling down the stairs in her apartment. She has a history of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Her current medications are alendronate, vitamin D, and calcium supplementation. Physical examination shows shortening of the right arm as well as tenderness and swelling over the right shoulder. The range of motion of the right arm is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right shoulder shows a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus. Which of the following movements is most likely to be impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired wrist extension and subsequent wrist drop due to weakness of the dorsal forearm muscles is a finding of proximal radial nerve injury. The radial nerve originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and travels adjacent to the deep brachial artery in the radial groove, where it is most susceptible to injury. It is most likely to be damaged because of a mid-shaft and distal humerus fracture, whereas this patient has a fracture of the proximal humerus. Injury to the radial nerve within the radial groove typically also results in sensory deficits over the posterior forearm and dorsal aspect of the thumb, second and third digit, and lateral fourth digit.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP joints

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2nd and 3rd fingers. The 1st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumb

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired elbow flexion due to weakness of the brachialis and coracobrachialis muscles is a sign of musculocutaneous nerve injury. This nerve arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus and travels downwards between the biceps brachii and the brachialis muscles. Because it is largely protected by the biceps, injury due to mid-shaft humerus fractures is rare. This patient's x-ray, however, shows a fracture of the proximal humerus. Excessive lateral flexion of the neck (e.g., trauma, football injuries) can lead to Erb palsy with injury to the musculocutaneous nerve. Further symptoms of musculocutaneous nerve injury include impaired forearm supination and sensory deficits over the lateral forearm.

C) CORRECT:

The axillary nerve originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and carries fibers from C5–6 through the quadrangular space to innervate the deltoid. Due to its proximity to the surgical neck of the humerus, the nerve can become injured by a proximal humerus fracture. Impaired arm abduction over 15 degrees due to weakness of the deltoid muscle is a classic finding of axillary nerve injury. Further symptoms of axillary nerve injury include impaired external rotation of the arm (due to paralysis of the teres minor muscle) and loss of sensation over the lateral shoulder.

Further common causes of axillary nerve palsy include anterior shoulder dislocation and iatrogenic injury (e.g., during shoulder reconstruction procedures, rotator cuff surgery).

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired thumb adduction due to weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle is a sign of proximal ulnar nerve injury (Froment sign). The ulnar nerve originates from the medial cord of the brachial plexus and runs along the posteromedial aspect of the humerus until passing through the cubital tunnel, where it is most superficial and susceptible to injury. It is most likely to be damaged due to a distal humerus fracture at the medial epicondyle, whereas this patient has a fracture of the proximal humerus. Further symptoms of proximal ulnar nerve injury include an ulnar claw and sensory deficits over the fourth and fifth digit.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired wrist flexion due to weakness of the ventral forearm muscles is a sign of proximal median nerve injury. The median nerve originates from the lateral and medial cord of the brachial plexus and crosses the elbow anteriorly with the brachial artery, where the nerve is most at risk for injury. It is most likely to be damaged due to a supracondylar humerus fracture, whereas this patient has a fracture of the proximal humerus. Further symptoms of proximal median nerve injury include the “hand of benediction” and sensory deficits over the palmar aspect of the first three digits and the radial side of the fourth digit.
Image Description:

AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve
questions.hint: Examination would likely also show flattening of the deltoid prominence.

questions.text: A 53-year-old multiparous woman is scheduled to undergo elective sling surgery for treatment of stress incontinence. She has frequent loss of small amounts of urine when she coughs or laughs, despite attempts at conservative treatment. The physician inserts trocars in the obturator foramen bilaterally to make the incision and passes a mesh around the pubic bones and underneath the urethra to form a sling. During the procedure, the physician accidentally injures a nerve in the obturator foramen. The function of which of the following muscles is most likely to be affected following the procedure?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The obturator internus muscle is supplied directly from the sacral plexus roots L5, S1, and S2. Although the muscle itself is dissected during midurethral sling surgery, the roots innervating this muscle pass through the greater sciatic foramen, not the obturator foramen, and are rarely damaged.

B) CORRECT:

The obturator nerve innervates the muscles of the medial compartment of the thigh, including the adductor longus, adductor magnus, adductor brevis, gracilis, external obturator, and, occasionally, the pectineus muscle. It is frequently damaged during midurethral sling surgeries, as well as by pelvic ring fractures and obturator hernias. Damage to this nerve can cause sensory deficits along the medial thigh and weakness of hip adduction.

C) INCORRECT:

The tensor fascia latae muscle is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve, which passes through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle and lies in the superomedial gluteal region. The superior gluteal nerve does not pass through the obturator foramen and is not typically injured in midurethral sling surgery. Instead, this nerve is typically injured by gluteal intramuscular injections.
Image Description:

A neural network formed by the anterior (ventral) divisions of the last two lumbar nerves and the first four sacral nerves (L4–S4).

The illustration depicts the nerve roots and branches of the sacral plexus that supply motor and sensory innervation to the lower limbs and pelvis.

Note that the nerve roots of the pudendal nerve are variably described in the literature as S2-S4 or S1-S4 (as depicted here).

D) INCORRECT:

The transversus abdominis muscle is innervated by the iliohypogastric nerve, which passes over the quadratus lumborum muscle of the posterior abdominal wall and is at risk of injury during abdominal surgery. Midurethral sling surgery is performed in the pelvic region and does not typically endanger the iliohypogastric nerve.
Image Description:

A neural network formed by the anterior (ventral) divisions of the subcostal and first four lumbar nerves (T12–L4).

The illustration depicts the nerve roots and branches of the lumbar plexus that supply motor and sensory innervation to the lower limbs and pelvis.

E) INCORRECT:

The rectus femoris muscle, which is part of the quadriceps femoris muscle, is innervated by the femoral nerve. The femoral nerve lies within the psoas major muscle of the posterior abdominal wall and enters the thigh by passing underneath the inguinal ligament. It can be injured during femoral vascular access procedures, abdominal surgery, and pelvic surgery. The nerve that was injured during this patient's pelvic procedure lies in the obturator foramen, which does not contain the femoral nerve.
Image Description:

The femoral nerve is the main nerve of the anterior compartment of the thigh. The saphenous nerve and the medial and intermediate cutaneous nerves of the thigh originate from the femoral nerve.
The obturator nerve is the main nerve of the medial compartment of the thigh and exits the pelvis ventrally through the obturator foramen.
The iliohypogastric, ilioinguinal, genitofemoral, and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves are pure sensory nerves that arise directly from the lumbar plexus.
The common fibular nerve (a terminal branch of the sciatic nerve) branches into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves at or just below the neck of the fibula.

Cutaneous innervation of the foot is supplied by the saphenous nerve medially and the sural nerve laterally.
Cutaneous innervation of the dorsum of the foot is supplied by branches of the superficial fibular nerve, with the exception of the first interdigital space, which is supplied by a branch of the deep fibular nerve.

F) INCORRECT:

The semitendinosus muscle is innervated by the sciatic nerve, which passes through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis muscle and lies in the gluteal region. The sciatic nerve does not pass through the obturator foramen and is not typically injured during midurethral sling surgery. Instead, this nerve is typically injured during hip joint surgeries and by gluteal intramuscular injections.
Image Description:

The nerves of the lower extremity arise from the lumbar and sacral plexuses.
The sciatic nerve (L4–S3), inferior gluteal nerve, posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh, and pudendal nerve exit the pelvis dorsally through the greater sciatic foramen, inferior to the piriformis muscle. The superior gluteal nerve is the only nerve that exits the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle.
The sciatic nerve branches at the popliteal fossa into the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve.

The cutaneous nerves penetrate through the deep fascia and enter the subcutaneous plane to supply their dermatomes.
The sural nerve is a cutaneous nerve formed by the union of the medial sural cutaneous nerve (originating from the tibial nerve) and the lateral sural cutaneous nerve (originating from the common peroneal nerve).
The medial and lateral plantar nerves are the cutaneous terminal branches of the tibial nerve.
questions.hint: The nerve passing through the obturator foramen is the obturator nerve, which is at risk of being injured during pelvic surgeries or as a result of pelvic trauma.

questions.text: Three months after undergoing amputation of the left lower extremity, a 27-year-old man, who is a military veteran, comes to the physician because of stabbing and burning stump pain. He reports that the pain sometimes “feels like an electrical shock that shoots up my limb” especially when he sits on the edge of the bed or stands up while using his prosthesis. The symptoms improved after he stopped using his prosthesis but have worsened after he began using it again 1 week ago. He uses ibuprofen for the pain which has provided minimal relief. The patient underwent above-the-knee amputation of the left leg after sustaining a blast injury during active combat. The surgical procedure was uncomplicated and postoperative care showed good wound healing. He has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a well-healed scar and intact skin overlying the stump. Palpation of the stump causes localized tenderness when pressure is applied to the area of the scar. Muscle strength is 5/5 throughout. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteomyelitis manifests with localized tenderness at the site of surgery and can be a source of chronic postoperative pain. However, osteomyelitis does not typically cause stabbing, burning, and radiating pain. Furthermore, classic signs of inflammation, such as swelling, redness, and warmth, as well as systemic symptoms (e.g., malaise, fever), are absent here.

B) INCORRECT:

Limb ischemia is a potential cause of postoperative pain but the quality of this patient's discomfort (burning, stabbing, radiating throughout the leg) makes ischemic pain unlikely. Pain due to ischemia manifests with intermittent claudication, rest pain, or atypical leg pain instead. Finally, this patient does not have any other signs of ischemia, such as ulceration and/or pallor.

C) INCORRECT:

Phantom limb syndrome, a complication of amputation, manifests with intermittent pain that can vary in character (e.g., burning, tingling, shooting sensation). Unlike this patient's pain, however, phantom limb pain occurs distal to the amputation level.

D) CORRECT:

Traumatic neuromas are benign tumors that occur in response to nerve injury (e.g., amputations). These lesions arise from the disorganized proliferation of nerve fibers or their myelin sheath and usually develop within the first year following amputation. Symptomatic stump neuromas commonly manifest with palpable tender nodules, neuropathic pain, and paresthesias, as well as numbness, cold intolerance, and positive Tinel sign at the neuroma site. Residual limb pain is characteristically located proximal to the amputation level.

Traumatic neuromas are typically a clinical diagnosis. MRI can be useful for differentiating neuromas from other causes of stump pain and often shows a well-demarcated bulbous mass at the nerve ending. Treatment includes conservative strategies (e.g., physical therapy), pharmacological pain management, anesthetic or steroid injections, prosthesis reshaping, and/or surgical excision.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone overgrowth after limb amputation manifests with pain and intolerance to the prosthesis. However, the burning, radiating, and stabbing nature of this patient's pain suggests a different condition. Moreover, bone overgrowth most commonly affects children and adolescents and is rarely seen in adults.
questions.hint: This patient presents with sharp, burning, and radiating pain that worsens when pressure is applied to the stump (i.e., prosthesis use), while the remainder of the examination is unremarkable.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the office for a follow-up examination. Three months ago, she underwent a left-sided radical mastectomy to treat breast cancer with axillary node involvement. She is recovering well from the surgery but has noticed difficulties combing her hair with her left hand. When asked to extend both arms and press them against a wall, her back appears as shown in the photograph. Sensation in the upper extremities is grossly intact. The nerve most likely injured during surgery originates from which of the following spinal roots?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The medial pectoral nerve receives nerve fibers from C8–T1 spinal roots. Surgery involving axillary lymph node dissection may injure the medial pectoral nerve, however, this would manifest in atrophy of the pectoralis major. Scapular winging would not be expected in this condition.

The lower trunk of the brachial plexus and the ulnar nerve also receive nerve fibers from C8–T1 spinal roots. Hyperabduction of the arm can cause lower brachial plexus palsy (Klumpke palsy), which would manifest in weakness of all the intrinsic muscles of the hand and sensory deficits on the medial side of the corresponding upper limb. Injury to the ulnar nerve results in weakness of the fourth and fifth lumbricals and sensory deficits in the fourth and fifth digits.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

B) INCORRECT:

The thoracodorsal nerve receives nerve fibers from the C6–C8 spinal roots. It lies along the posterior axillary wall, making it vulnerable to injury during a radical mastectomy. Injury to this nerve causes weakness of the latissimus dorsi and teres major and manifests with impaired internal rotation and adduction of the arm. Scapular winging or difficulty with combing hair would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Each thoracic intercostal nerve arises from the corresponding spinal root (e.g., second intercostal nerve from T2 spinal root) and innervates the corresponding intercostal muscle. The second to fifth intercostal nerves also innervate the serratus posterior superior muscle. Intercostal nerve injury typically occurs during the placement of a chest drain or thoracotomy. However, the muscles innervated by these nerves are accessory respiratory muscles, and their paralysis is clinically insignificant as long as the diaphragm functions. Neuralgic pain is the only significant symptom following intercostal nerve injury.
Image Description:

Illustration of the intercostal artery, vein, and nerve (forming the intercostal neurovascular bundle) within the costal groove

As the pathway of these structures follows the inferior edge of the ribs, medical interventions (e.g., chest tube insertion) are always performed along the superior edge of the rib. The order of the structures of the neurovascular bundle can be remembered using the acronym “VAN”: the intercostal vein (V) is superior, the artery (A) is in the middle, and the nerve (N) is inferior.

D) INCORRECT:

The phrenic nerve arises from the C3–C5 spinal roots and innervates the diaphragm and pericardium. It can be injured during anterior scalenectomy, open heart or thoracoscopic mediastinal surgery, pulmonary vein radiofrequency ablation, and IVC clamping during hepatectomy or liver transplantation. Phrenic nerve injury manifests with dyspnea and, in the case of unilateral palsy, asymmetric chest movement. Scapular winging or difficulty with combing hair would not be expected.

E) CORRECT:

The long thoracic nerve originates directly from the C5–C7 anterior spinal roots, enters the axillary cavity, and descends together with the lateral thoracic artery along the lateral surface of the thoracic cage. Long thoracic nerve injury is commonly caused by axillary surgery (e.g., radical mastectomy), direct trauma to the shoulder, and prolonged nerve compression (e.g., carrying a heavy backpack). This injury leads to paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle, which manifests with medial winging of the scapula and weakened abduction of the shoulder above 90° (manifesting, e.g., when combing hair). Management of scapular winging due to nerve palsy consists of observation and conservative management, as most cases resolve spontaneously in 6 to 24 months. Osteopathic treatment includes targeting somatic dysfunctions of the cervical spine, thoracic spine, or upper extremity, muscle strengthening exercises for the serratus anterior, and treatment of any restrictions in motion in ribs 6–9.

The musculocutaneous nerve also receives nerve fibers from C5–C7 spinal roots, but it arises as a branch of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus rather than directly from the spinal roots. Injury to the musculocutaneous nerve (e.g., a gunshot wound in the arm) manifests with loss of sensation over the lateral forearm and impaired flexion and supination of the forearm.
questions.hint: The image shows winging of the scapula, which is characteristic of long thoracic nerve injury.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and obesity reports pain in the area of the left anterolateral hip and thigh that has been present for a few months but has worsened during the past few weeks. The pain is moderate and burning in character. She states that she has sustained no injury to that area. She is able to walk without difficulty.
On examination, her vital signs are normal. She has normal lumbar flexion, a negative straight-leg-raise test, and no edema or tenderness on palpation of the left lateral hip or midthigh. On neurologic examination, she has normal strength, but a loss of sensation in the left anterolateral thigh.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Compression of the left common iliac vein by the right common iliac artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Compression of the left common iliac vein by the right common iliac artery (May-Thurner syndrome) may cause groin pain, thrombosis, and stasis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and examination suggest meralgia paresthetica, which is caused by the entrapment of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve at the inguinal ligament. Risk factors for the condition include obesity, type 2 diabetes, older age, and tight-fitting garments. The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is a purely sensory nerve that innervates the skin on the anterolateral hip to midthigh.

Key learning point: The typical presentation of meralgia paresthetica is pain and loss of sensation in the anterolateral thigh.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar radiculopathy could manifest with neuropathic features, but it typically is not localized to the anterolateral thigh alone, and it would usually be associated with some degree of back pain or discomfort.

D) INCORRECT:

Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (formerly referred to as trochanteric bursitis) causes tenderness on palpation of the greater trochanter.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetic amyotrophy is characterized by weakness followed by wasting of the pelvifemoral muscles, either unilaterally or bilaterally, with associated severe pain.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and a 40-pack-year history of cigarette smoking reports 3 months of right shoulder pain that radiates down her arm. Her symptoms have persisted and progressed despite a course of physical therapy and use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications and acetaminophen.
On examination, her right shoulder has full range of motion and is not swollen or tender to palpation. She has wasting of the intrinsic muscles of the right hand. Lung examination is remarkable for mild bilateral expiratory wheezing. Palpation of her right axilla reveals no masses.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Electromyography and nerve-conduction studies in the right arm are likely to suggest a brachial plexopathy but will not reveal its cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient with a significant history of cigarette smoking, the presence of shoulder pain with muscle wasting in the ipsilateral distal extremity and a normal shoulder examination should suggest the possibility of an upper thoracic tumor compressing or invading the brachial plexus. These tumors, called superior pulmonary sulcus or Pancoast tumors, are typically due to non-small-cell lung cancers. The pain that patients experience is due to invasion of the tumor into the brachial plexus or through extension of the tumor into the parietal pleura, ribs, or vertebra. These tumors can also invade the sympathetic chain and inferior cervical ganglion and cause Horner syndrome. The most appropriate next step is to obtain a chest radiograph.

Key learning point: Shoulder pain and wasting of the small muscles of the hand in a patient with a long history of cigarette smoking should prompt evaluation for superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast tumor) with a chest radiograph.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A heterogeneous mass-like opacity (red overlay) in the right apex extends to a thickened irregular pleural surface (blue overlay). Other vague areas of soft tissue density are also present in the right apex (green overlay), and the posterior cortices of the right 3rd, 4th, and 5th ribs (indicated by white dashed outlines) are not fully visualized as a result of tumor invasion.

The findings are consistent with a Pancoast tumor with chest wall extension.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical spine disease can manifest with pain that radiates to the shoulder or radicular neurologic findings in the arm; however, the first priority in this case is to rule out a superior pulmonary sulcus tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with hypertension, insulin-requiring diabetes mellitus, end-stage kidney disease, and a distant history of cigarette smoking presents with new-onset pain in her right shoulder and weakness in her right hand that have progressed during the past 6 weeks. In addition, she has lost 15 pounds during the past 4 months.
Physical examination reveals a unilateral, right-sided ptosis with a pinpoint pupil of the right eye, as well as muscle atrophy, hand weakness, and numbness in the fourth and fifth fingers of the right hand. No facial plethora is noted. The patient has no pain on percussion of her neck or back.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis leads to renal insufficiency and can cause sensorimotor neuropathy but is not associated with the development of Horner syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Although myasthenia gravis can cause ptosis and muscle weakness, it is not associated with miosis (a component of Horner syndrome).

C) INCORRECT:

Although carotid artery dissection could progress to stroke and subsequently cause arm weakness, this event would likely occur more acutely than the gradual development of Horner syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Tumors of the superior pulmonary sulcus, also called Pancoast tumors, can cause a classic presentation by compressing against nerve structures as they pass through or near the thoracic inlet. Compression of the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots can cause pain and neurologic compromise of those nerves. In addition, interruption of the sympathetic nerve chain running to the head can result in Horner syndrome, which is characterized by unilateral miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis. Treatment of superior pulmonary sulcus tumors involves multidisciplinary care coordinated among a thoracic surgeon, a radiation oncologist, and a medical oncologist.

Key learning point: The gradual development of arm weakness and Horner syndrome in an older patient with a history of cigarette smoking is most indicative of a diagnosis of a superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast) tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Arm weakness and numbness in the fingers is more consistent with a dermatomal distribution than with a brainstem lesion.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents 2 days after injuring his right upper extremity while playing football. The injury occurred after he tackled another player in an awkward fashion with his head down, forcing his neck to bend laterally to the right. He developed acute pain that shot down his right arm accompanied by numbness, tingling, and weakness. The pain and weakness quickly resolved, but mild numbness in the forearm and hand persisted for about 36 hours.
The neck, shoulder, and upper extremity are normal to inspection and palpation, with normal range of motion and normal strength. Neer, Hawkins, Speed, and Spurling tests are all normal.
What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding this patient’s return to play football?

choices.text: Obtain a cervical spine radiograph; if normal, return to play immediately
Repeat the physical examination in one week; if unremarkable, return to play
Obtain an electromyogram; if normal, return to play immediately
Avoid contact sports for at least 6 weeks
Avoid contact sports for at least 3 months

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This young athlete sustained a “stinger” or “burner,” a common upper-neck or upper-extremity injury in contact and collision sports. The exact mechanism is unknown, but it is thought to arise from either cervical nerve-root compression or brachial plexus tension/compression and is therefore also sometimes called traumatic brachial plexus injury. Symptoms usually consist of transient upper-extremity shooting pain with or without associated paresthesias and weakness.

In an isolated first-time injury with rapidly resolving symptoms (seconds to minutes) and a normal physical examination, same-game return to play may be appropriate. However, if symptoms persist for more than a few minutes, the athlete should sit out the rest of the game and be evaluated again at the end of the game; if symptoms still persist, then additional evaluation is indicated.

Imaging of the neck with cervical spine radiographs to evaluate for cervical spinal stenosis, bone injury, or cervical ligament injury is indicated after a stinger injury if the patient has any of the following features:

• Symptoms that persist >24 hours
• Limited motion of the cervical spine
• Midline tenderness of the cervical spine
• Severe pain
• Repeated episodes (>2 or 3)

In this patient, whose symptoms persisted for 36 hours, cervical spine radiographs should be obtained. Imaging beyond plain radiographs (i.e., CT or MRI) is typically indicated only if other pathologies are suspected; electromyography is not routinely indicated.

If the imaging results are normal and the athlete is asymptomatic in a practice setting, he can reasonably return to play without restriction.

Persistent symptoms or imaging abnormalities are contraindications to return to play, and further workup should be pursued as appropriate.

Key learning point: Imaging with cervical spine radiography is indicated in patients with a traumatic brachial plexus injury (stinger injury) if symptoms persist >24 hours, there are repeated episodes, or there are atypical features such as limited motion, tenderness, or severe pain.

B) INCORRECT:

In an isolated first-time injury with rapidly resolving symptoms (seconds to minutes) and a normal physical examination, same-game return to play may be appropriate. However, if symptoms persist for more than a few minutes, the athlete should sit out the rest of the game and be evaluated again at the end of the game; if symptoms still persist, then additional evaluation is indicated.

In this patient, whose symptoms persisted for 36 hours, cervical spine radiographs should be obtained. If the imaging results are normal and the athlete is asymptomatic in a practice setting, he can reasonably return to play without restriction.

C) INCORRECT:

Electromyography is not routinely indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

In this patient, whose symptoms persisted for 36 hours, cervical spine radiographs should be obtained. If the imaging results are normal and the athlete is asymptomatic in a practice setting, he can reasonably return to play without restriction.

Persistent symptoms or imaging abnormalities are contraindications to return to play, and further workup should be pursued as appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

In this patient, whose symptoms persisted for 36 hours, cervical spine radiographs should be obtained. If the imaging results are normal and the athlete is asymptomatic in a practice setting, he can reasonably return to play without restriction.

Persistent symptoms or imaging abnormalities are contraindications to return to play, and further workup should be pursued as appropriate.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old female college basketball player presents with left shoulder pain and weakness in her left arm after being injured during a game 2 days ago. She was fighting for a rebound when an opposing player came down hard on the superior aspect of her left shoulder. She experienced immediate pain and weakness in her shoulder and arm, so she withdrew from play.
She reports that the pain has improved with rest, ice, and use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medication, but some nonspecific left-arm weakness persists. She has no neck pain currently, and she has no history of similar symptoms.
Which one of the following examination findings is this patient most likely to have?

choices.text: Diminished sensation over the back of the hand

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A brachial plexopathy (also called a “stinger” or “burner”) is a unilateral traumatic injury to the brachial plexus that results in transient pain and, sometimes, weakness in the affected upper extremity. It is caused by traction, compression, or direct trauma. The upper nerve roots are most commonly injured. Symptoms often last for only minutes but may last much longer in some cases.

When symptoms do not resolve quickly, physical examination can help distinguish a brachial plexopathy from other causes of neck and upper-extremity pain. The type of weakness related to a brachial plexopathy depends on the nerve roots affected. In the most common cases, involving the upper trunk, there is weakness of the deltoid, biceps, and rotator cuff, all of which are innervated at the C5–C6 levels of the upper trunk. Another possible finding is a positive Tinel sign at Erb point; pain is reproduced by tapping on the area 2 to 3 cm above the clavicle on the affected side. This area corresponds to the convergence of the C5 and C6 nerve roots.

Key learning point: Brachial plexopathy is most commonly associated with weakness upon shoulder abduction.

B) INCORRECT:

Radial pulses should be unaffected by a true plexopathy. Diminished pulses would be more likely to be seen in an entity such as thoracic outlet syndrome. Typically, this syndrome has a more insidious onset and would not be expected to manifest acutely after a shoulder injury.

C) INCORRECT:

Weakness of triceps extension and diminished sensation of the C8 distribution, which includes the back of the arm and hand, would not be expected, as brachial plexopathy typically manifests with sensory and motor changes in the upper distributions rather than the lower levels (such as C7, which innervates the triceps reflex, and C8).

D) INCORRECT:

Weakness of triceps extension and diminished sensation of the C8 distribution, which includes the back of the arm and hand, would not be expected, as brachial plexopathy typically manifests with sensory and motor changes in the upper distributions rather than the lower levels (such as C7, which innervates the triceps reflex, and C8).

E) INCORRECT:

Diminished (not increased) deep-tendon reflexes may be evident at the site of injury.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and a 40-pack-year history of cigarette smoking reports 3 months of right shoulder pain that radiates down her arm. Her symptoms have persisted and progressed despite a course of physical therapy and use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications and acetaminophen. On examination, her right shoulder has full range of motion and is not swollen or tender to palpation. She has wasting of the intrinsic muscles of the right hand. Lung examination is remarkable for mild bilateral expiratory wheezing. Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Electromyography and nerve-conduction studies in the right arm are likely to suggest a brachial plexopathy but will not reveal its cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient with a significant history of cigarette smoking, the presence of shoulder pain with muscle wasting in the ipsilateral distal extremity and a normal shoulder examination should suggest the possibility of an upper thoracic tumor compressing or invading the brachial plexus. These tumors, called superior pulmonary sulcus or Pancoast tumors, are typically due to non-small-cell lung cancers. The pain that patients experience is due to invasion of the tumor into the brachial plexus or through extension of the tumor into the parietal pleura, ribs, or vertebra. These tumors can also invade the sympathetic chain and inferior cervical ganglion and cause Horner syndrome. The most appropriate next step is to obtain a chest radiograph.

Key learning point: Shoulder pain and wasting of the small muscles of the hand in a patient with a long history of cigarette smoking should prompt evaluation for superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast tumor) with a chest radiograph.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A heterogeneous mass-like opacity (red overlay) in the right apex extends to a thickened irregular pleural surface (blue overlay). Other vague areas of soft tissue density are also present in the right apex (green overlay), and the posterior cortices of the right 3rd, 4th, and 5th ribs (indicated by white dashed outlines) are not fully visualized as a result of tumor invasion.

The findings are consistent with a Pancoast tumor with chest wall extension.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical spine disease can manifest with pain that radiates to the shoulder or radicular neurologic findings in the arm; however, the first priority in this case is to rule out a superior pulmonary sulcus tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

questions.text: Seven hours after undergoing left hip arthroplasty for chronic hip pain, a 67-year-old woman reports a prickling sensation in her left anteromedial thigh and lower leg. Neurologic examination shows left leg strength 3/5 on hip flexion and 2/5 on knee extension. Patellar reflex is decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch are decreased on the anteromedial left thigh as well as medial lower leg. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has evidence of femoral nerve injury, likely from prolonged compression during surgery. Injury of the femoral nerve typically results in loss of sensation in the anteromedial thigh and medial lower leg (anterior cutaneous branches), as well as decreased strength in hip flexion (iliopsoas muscle) and knee extension (quadriceps femoris muscle).

B) INCORRECT:

Fibular nerve injury is usually caused by injuries in the lower leg (e.g., fracture of the fibular head or tight-fitting casts of the lower leg). It typically presents with foot drop (weakness of foot dorsiflexors) and a loss of sensation between the first and second toe (deep peroneal nerve branch) and the back of the feet and toes (superficial peroneal nerve branch). Fibular nerve injury would not cause loss of sensation in the anteromedial thigh or the decreased knee extension seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Obturator nerve injury usually results from pelvic ring fractures or entrapment. It typically manifests with loss of sensation of the medial thigh (cutaneous branch of the obturator nerve) and decreased strength in the hip adductors. It would not explain this patient's loss of sensation in the anterior thigh or her decreased strength in knee extension.

D) INCORRECT:

S1 radiculopathy typically causes back pain that radiates down the posterior leg into the foot, with sensory loss along the lateral foot, weakness in plantar flexion and eversion, and a decreased Achilles tendon reflex. This patient's symptoms are localized to different areas and do not follow a radicular pattern.

E) INCORRECT:

L5 radiculopathy typically causes back pain that radiates down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot, with sensory loss along the lateral aspect of the lower leg and dorsum of the foot and strength deficits in foot dorsiflexion and eversion. This patient's symptoms are localized to different areas and do not follow a radicular pattern.
questions.hint: Postoperative anteromedial thigh and lower leg paresthesias with concurrent decreased patellar reflex, hip flexion, and knee extension are consistent with damage to a peripheral nerve of the anterior lower extremity.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit. She reports dull aching pain and paresthesia over her left hand for the last few weeks. The pain radiates to her shoulder and is worse at night. Her hand feels numb upon waking up in the morning. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the wrist is passively held in full flexion, aggravation of paresthesia is perceived immediately. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Lower trunk palsy of the brachial plexus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paralysis of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Klumpke palsy) causes deficits along the C8 and T1 myotomes and dermatomes. Although Klumpke palsy may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand and would also be present on the ulnar aspect of the forearm. Hand and finger weakness is also typically prominent. In addition, this patient lacks a history that would suggest Klumpke paralysis (e.g., upward traction on the arm, thoracic outlet syndrome, Pancoast tumor).

B) INCORRECT:

Compression of the ulnar nerve in the ulnar groove between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon (cubital tunnel syndrome) may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand as seen in this patient. However, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand, and/or the ring and little finger and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with ulnar nerve compression. Also, this patient has no history that would suggest a cubital tunnel syndrome (e.g., osteoarthritis or trauma to the elbow).

C) INCORRECT:

Radiculopathy of C6, C7, and/or C8 nerve roots may manifest with pain and paresthesia in the hand and shoulder. However, radiculopathy is typically accompanied by restriction of neck, arm, or hand movements. Also, nocturnal paresthesia is usually not present. Exacerbation of paresthesia by passive flexion of the wrist (Phalen sign) suggests a specific mononeuropathy and not radiculopathy.

D) CORRECT:

Compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel (carpal tunnel syndrome, CTS) results in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the areas innervated by the median nerve (i.e., palmar surface of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, and radial half of the ring finger). Pregnancy is an important risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome because of physiological fluid retention, which leads to edema of soft tissue in and around the carpal tunnel. The sensory disturbances in CTS are classically worse at night and pain on flexion of the wrist (a positive Phalen test) may be present. Occasionally, the pain may radiate to the shoulder, as seen in this patient. Most cases of carpal tunnel syndrome with an onset during pregnancy can be managed by splinting of the wrist. Surgery and corticosteroid injections are usually not required because symptoms usually resolve after delivery.

Key learning point: Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by median nerve compression at the wrist, leading to nocturnal pain and paresthesia in the lateral hand, often worsened by wrist flexion.
Image Description:

The Phalen maneuver is considered specific for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The examiner holds the patient's wrist in flexion (1) or extension (2). If paresthesia in the fingers innervated by the median nerve (marked in white) occurs or is aggravated within one minute, this finding is highly specific for CTS.

E) INCORRECT:

Radial nerve compression usually results from trauma or prolonged pressure on the mid-arm (e.g., Saturday night palsy). Radial nerve palsy typically manifests with sensory changes over the posterior forearm/hand and weakness on wrist extension (i.e., wrist drop). This patient has no significant risk factors for radial nerve compression (e.g., trauma or intoxication) and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with radial nerve compression.
questions.hint: Beside pregnancy, hypothyroidism and rheumatoid arthritis are also risk factors for this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after injuring his knee during a high-impact football tackle. He reports sudden onset of severe pain over the lateral knee and difficulty lifting his foot while walking. Examination shows weakness in dorsiflexion of the ankle, reduced sensation over the dorsum of the foot, and a prominent bruise at the fibular neck. Radiographs confirm a displaced fracture at the fibular neck.
Which nerve is most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The sural nerve is a sensory nerve supplying the lateral foot. It does not innervate muscles responsible for dorsiflexion. Injury to the sural nerve would cause sensory loss in its territory but not motor deficits like dorsiflexion weakness. The fibular neck fracture affects a nerve with both motor and sensory functions.

B) CORRECT:

The common peroneal nerve, also known as the common fibular nerve, wraps around the fibular neck, making it vulnerable to injury in fractures at this site. Damage to this nerve results in weakness in dorsiflexion, leading to foot drop, and sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot. Its superficial position and proximity to the lateral knee structures increase its susceptibility to trauma, particularly in high-impact injuries.

Key learning point: The common peroneal nerve is most vulnerable to injury in fractures of the fibular head and neck due to its anatomical location wrapping around the fibula.

C) INCORRECT:

The tibial nerve innervates muscles responsible for plantar flexion and provides sensation to the plantar aspect of the foot. Injury to the tibial nerve would manifest as weakness in plantar flexion and sensory deficits on the sole, not dorsiflexion weakness or sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot. The tibial nerve does not course near the fibular neck.

D) INCORRECT:

The saphenous nerve is a sensory branch of the femoral nerve, innervating the medial leg and foot. It does not supply the dorsum of the foot or contribute to motor function. Its course is along the medial knee, not near the fibular neck, making it unlikely to be injured in this context.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after falling off his motorcycle. He complains of pain around his upper leg. On examination, he is unable to dorsiflex the foot at the ankle and has a drop foot posture. There is diminished sensation between the first and second toes. Plantar flexion is preserved, and the Achilles tendon reflex is intact. No other deficits are noted.
Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The deep peroneal nerve, a branch of the common peroneal nerve, innervates the anterior compartment of the leg, including muscles like the tibialis anterior, which facilitate dorsiflexion. Injury to this nerve results in foot drop due to loss of dorsiflexion. It also provides sensory innervation to the web space between the first and second toes, explaining the diminished sensation in that area. Preservation of plantar flexion and an intact Achilles tendon reflex indicate that the tibial nerve is unaffected, supporting the diagnosis of deep peroneal nerve injury.

Key learning point: Injury to the deep peroneal nerve results in impaired dorsiflexion of the foot and sensory loss in the web space between the first and second toes.

B) INCORRECT:

The tibial nerve innervates the posterior compartment of the leg, responsible for plantar flexion, and provides sensation to the sole of the foot. The patient's preserved plantar flexion and intact Achilles tendon reflex indicate normal tibial nerve function. The deficits observed are consistent with deep peroneal nerve injury.

C) INCORRECT:

The saphenous nerve, a branch of the femoral nerve, is purely sensory and supplies the medial aspect of the leg and foot. It does not affect dorsiflexion or sensation between the first and second toes. The patient's motor and sensory deficits align with deep peroneal nerve injury, not saphenous nerve injury.

D) INCORRECT:

The superficial peroneal nerve innervates muscles that evert the foot and provides sensory innervation to most of the dorsum of the foot, excluding the area between the first and second toes. The patient's inability to dorsiflex the foot and sensory loss between the first and second toes are consistent with deep peroneal nerve injury, not superficial peroneal nerve injury.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after a soccer injury. He collided with another player and fell on his lateral knee while running. He complains of severe pain near the fibular head. Examination shows localized tenderness at the proximal fibula, foot drop with weakness on dorsiflexion, and decreased sensation over most of the dorsum of the foot. Radiographs confirm a fracture of the fibular neck.
Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The common peroneal nerve is susceptible to injury at the fibular neck due to its superficial location and minimal soft tissue protection. It divides into the deep and superficial peroneal nerves. The deep branch innervates muscles responsible for dorsiflexion, such as the tibialis anterior, while the superficial branch provides sensory innervation to the lateral and dorsal aspects of the foot. The clinical presentation of foot drop, weakness in dorsiflexion, and decreased sensation over the dorsum of the foot aligns with common peroneal nerve injury.

Key learning point: The common peroneal nerve is vulnerable to injury in fractures of the fibular head and neck due to its anatomical location, leading to potential foot drop.
Image Description:

The femoral nerve is the main nerve of the anterior compartment of the thigh. The saphenous nerve and the medial and intermediate cutaneous nerves of the thigh originate from the femoral nerve.
The obturator nerve is the main nerve of the medial compartment of the thigh and exits the pelvis ventrally through the obturator foramen.
The iliohypogastric, ilioinguinal, genitofemoral, and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves are pure sensory nerves that arise directly from the lumbar plexus.
The common fibular nerve (a terminal branch of the sciatic nerve) branches into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves at or just below the neck of the fibula.

Cutaneous innervation of the foot is supplied by the saphenous nerve medially and the sural nerve laterally.
Cutaneous innervation of the dorsum of the foot is supplied by branches of the superficial fibular nerve, with the exception of the first interdigital space, which is supplied by a branch of the deep fibular nerve.

B) INCORRECT:

The superficial peroneal nerve provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot and motor innervation to the peroneal muscles, which facilitate eversion. However, it does not innervate the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion, such as the tibialis anterior. The presence of foot drop and weakness in dorsiflexion indicates involvement of the deep peroneal nerve, a branch of the common peroneal nerve, rather than the superficial peroneal nerve alone.

C) INCORRECT:

The tibial nerve innervates the posterior compartment of the leg, responsible for plantar flexion and sensation over the sole of the foot. Injury to the tibial nerve would result in weakness in plantar flexion and sensory loss on the plantar surface, not foot drop or decreased sensation on the dorsum of the foot. Its medial course makes it less likely to be injured in a fibular neck fracture.

D) INCORRECT:

The saphenous nerve, a sensory branch of the femoral nerve, innervates the medial aspect of the leg. It does not contribute to motor function or sensation in the dorsum of the foot. The clinical findings of foot drop and decreased sensation over the dorsum of the foot suggest involvement of a nerve with both motor and sensory functions in this distribution, which the saphenous nerve does not provide.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old right-handed carpenter presents to the clinic after falling off a step ladder and striking his left arm against a railing. He reports weakness in straightening his left wrist and fingers, and numbness over the dorsal aspect of the left hand near the base of his thumb. Elbow flexion is preserved. Examination shows normal triceps function, an intact biceps reflex, and mild tenderness over the mid-humerus. Preliminary imaging shows no fracture.
Which additional physical exam finding is most likely present?

choices.text: Inability to abduct the little finger
Loss of sensation over the palmar aspect of digits 1 to 3

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inability to abduct the little finger indicates ulnar nerve dysfunction, affecting the dorsal interossei muscles. The patient's symptoms, including wrist and finger extension weakness and dorsal hand sensory loss, are consistent with radial nerve injury, not ulnar nerve involvement.

B) CORRECT:

Radial nerve injury at the mid-humerus level can impair muscles it innervates, including the brachioradialis. The brachioradialis reflex, elicited by tapping near the lateral epicondyle, may be diminished. The patient's wrist drop and sensory disturbance over the dorsal hand near the thumb base indicate radial nerve dysfunction. Preserved elbow flexion and triceps function suggest the injury spares the musculocutaneous nerve and the radial nerve branch to the triceps. A diminished brachioradialis reflex further localizes the lesion to the radial nerve fibers responsible for wrist extension.

Key learning point: Radial nerve injury can cause sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand and weakness in wrist and finger extension.

C) INCORRECT:

Loss of sensation over the palmar aspect of digits 1 to 3 suggests a median nerve lesion, which affects thumb opposition and forearm pronation. The patient's symptoms, including wrist drop and dorsal hand numbness, align with radial nerve injury, not median nerve dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Marked weakness of elbow extension would suggest a proximal radial nerve injury affecting the triceps. The patient's normal triceps strength and intact biceps reflex indicate the injury is distal to the radial nerve branch innervating the triceps, consistent with mid-humerus radial nerve dysfunction.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department with a deep laceration over the volar aspect of his right forearm after an accident with a piece of sheet metal at work. He cannot flex his ring and small fingers and has decreased sensation in the ulnar side of the palm. The wound is fresh with minimal contamination, bleeding is controlled, and no major vessels appear compromised. Vital signs are stable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Immobilization in a short arm cast for six weeks
Urgent surgical exploration and primary repair of the injured structures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous corticosteroids are used in inflammatory conditions or acute spinal cord injuries, not for mechanical nerve injuries from sharp trauma. The mainstay treatment for such injuries is surgical exploration and repair, as corticosteroids do not address structural nerve discontinuity.

B) INCORRECT:

Immobilization is part of post-operative care following tendon repairs, not the initial step for a fresh laceration with nerve and tendon injury. The clinical findings indicate a need for immediate surgical exploration and repair, not conservative management.

C) INCORRECT:

Delayed primary repair is reserved for wounds with significant contamination or infection risk. The described injury is a fresh laceration with minimal contamination, making immediate intervention favorable. Early nerve repair minimizes scar formation and optimizes nerve fiber alignment, crucial for functional recovery.

D) CORRECT:

A deep laceration on the volar forearm with motor and sensory deficits suggests a complete transection of the ulnar nerve. Urgent surgical exploration is necessary to assess the extent of the injury, debride nonviable tissue, and perform primary repair, typically through direct end-to-end anastomosis. Immediate repair in a fresh, minimally contaminated wound is crucial for optimal axonal regeneration and to minimize scar tissue formation, which could impede reinnervation. This approach is standard for sharp transection nerve injuries, offering the best chance for functional recovery.
