Key learning point: In cases of clean tendon and nerve lacerations, primary repair of the injured structures is essential to restore function and prevent long-term disability.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old runner presents with progressive difficulty “pushing off” while running for the past two weeks. He denies numbness but notes occasional tingling in the sole of his foot. On examination, there is noticeable weakness in plantarflexion, and he cannot fully stand on tiptoes on the affected side. Sensation is normal over the dorsum of the foot but decreased over the sole. His Achilles reflex is reduced.
Which nerve function is most likely impaired?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The superficial fibular nerve innervates muscles for foot eversion and provides sensation to the dorsum of the foot. The patient's plantarflexion weakness and sole sensory loss do not match the superficial fibular nerve's distribution.

B) INCORRECT:

The deep fibular nerve innervates muscles for dorsiflexion and toe extension, with sensory innervation limited to the first web space. The patient's plantarflexion weakness, sole sensory loss, and reduced Achilles reflex do not align with deep fibular nerve dysfunction.

C) CORRECT:

The tibial nerve innervates muscles responsible for plantarflexion, such as the gastrocnemius and soleus, crucial for the push-off phase in running. Impairment leads to plantarflexion weakness and inability to stand on tiptoes. It also provides sensory innervation to the plantar surface of the foot, explaining the decreased sensation there. The reduced Achilles reflex further indicates tibial nerve dysfunction, highlighting its role in lower limb motor and sensory deficits.

Key learning point: The tibial nerve innervates the muscles responsible for plantarflexion of the foot, such as the gastrocnemius and soleus, which are tested by standing on tiptoes.

D) INCORRECT:

The sural nerve is a sensory nerve providing sensation to the lateral lower leg and foot. The patient's plantarflexion weakness and sole sensory loss suggest involvement of a nerve with motor and sensory functions, unlike the purely sensory sural nerve.

questions.text:
An 18-hour-old newborn, weighing 4.4 kg at birth, was delivered vaginally to a 29-year-old woman in the Delivery Room. She has poorly controlled gestational diabetes. The delivery was complicated by shoulder dystocia requiring additional maneuvers. Physical examination shows diminished movement of the right upper extremity, especially at the shoulder, and an asymmetric Moro reflex with the right arm remaining limply by the side. There is mild swelling around the right shoulder with no tenderness on palpation.
Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Avulsion of nerve fibers from the C8 and T1 nerve roots
Injury to nerve fibers from the C5 and C6 nerve roots

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Avulsion of the C8 and T1 nerve roots affects the intrinsic hand muscles, often causing a claw hand deformity and possibly Horner syndrome. The clinical presentation of diminished shoulder movement and an asymmetric Moro reflex suggests involvement of the upper brachial plexus, not the lower trunk.

B) CORRECT:

Erb palsy results from an upper brachial plexus injury involving the C5 and C6 nerve roots, often due to lateral traction during delivery, especially in macrosomic infants. This injury affects the deltoid and biceps brachii muscles, leading to weakness in shoulder abduction and external rotation. The clinical presentation includes diminished shoulder movement and an asymmetric Moro reflex, with the affected arm remaining limp. These findings align with the typical motor deficits seen in Erb palsy.

Key learning point: In a large for gestational age infant born to a diabetic mother, an absent Moro reflex on one side is suggestive of Erb palsy, a brachial plexus injury often associated with shoulder dystocia during delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, and its injury leads to scapular winging, not limited shoulder movement. The clinical findings of a limp arm and asymmetric Moro reflex indicate an upper brachial plexus injury rather than long thoracic nerve compression.

D) INCORRECT:

Proximal humeral fractures typically present with tenderness, significant swelling, and sometimes crepitus. The absence of tenderness and the presence of diminished shoulder movement and an asymmetric Moro reflex suggest a brachial plexus injury rather than a fracture.

questions.text: You have just delivered a 4390-g male newborn at term to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus. Labor was prolonged due to impaction of the fetal shoulder, requiring hyperabduction of the left upper extremity. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Vital signs are normal. On examination in the delivery room, the newborn has a constricted left pupil and drooping of the left eyelid. There is reduced active movement of the left upper extremity. Further evaluation of this newborn is most likely to show which one of the following?

choices.text: Decreased movement of unilateral rib cage.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An absent nasolabial fold suggests a cranial nerve (CN) VII injury, which most commonly results from a forceps-assisted delivery. Although this patient has other facial abnormalities (ptosis and miosis), these findings are due to sympathetic nerve injury originating from the brachial plexus. CN VII fibers do not run within the brachial plexus, and thus facial droop is not associated with this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Unilateral phrenic nerve palsy can cause decreased movement of the ipsilateral rib cage and respiratory distress in the newborn. Phrenic nerve palsy can be a rare complication of a brachial plexus injury. Although this infant has evidence of brachial plexus injury (i.e., ptosis, miosis, decreased arm movement), he has no respiratory issues and normal vital signs, making phrenic nerve palsy unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

A unilateral wrist drop can occur after injury to the radial nerve (e.g., mid-shaft fracture of the humerus) or injury to the posterior cord of the brachial plexus (e.g., penetrating trauma below the clavicle). However, neither radial nerve injury nor posterior cord injury would manifest with ptosis and miosis, which suggests that this patient has a different brachial plexus injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Crepitus in the upper chest suggests a clavicular fracture for which this infant is at increased risk because of his traumatic birthing process. Although a clavicular fracture is usually asymptomatic, it can manifest as pseudoparalysis with reduced movement of the arm (due to pain), as seen in this infant. However, the presence of ptosis and miosis suggests a brachial plexus injury and not pseudoparalysis.

E) CORRECT:

Klumpke palsy is due to injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8–T1), which can result from hyperabduction (excessive upward traction) of the arm during delivery. Concurrent injury to cervical sympathetic fibers may result in Horner syndrome (miosis and ptosis). Since C8 and T1 nerve fibers supply the ipsilateral intrinsic hand muscles, Klumpke palsy causes an absent grasp reflex. Treatment for Klumpke palsy consists of passive range of motion exercises, and most infants will gain normal strength within the first couple of months of life.

Key learning point: Klumpke palsy results from injury to the lower brachial plexus (C8–T1), causing an absent grasp reflex and may be associated with Horner syndrome.
questions.hint: Shoulder dystocia is a complication that can occur in macrosomic neonates born to mothers with diabetes mellitus. Obstetric maneuvers used to help deliver babies with shoulder dystocia can cause brachial plexus injury.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and a 40-pack-year smoking history comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of right shoulder pain radiating down her arm. Her symptoms have persisted and worsened despite physical therapy, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications, and acetaminophen. On examination, her right shoulder has full range of motion and is not swollen or tender to palpation. There is wasting of the intrinsic muscles of her right hand. Lung examination reveals mild bilateral expiratory wheezing. Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Electromyography and nerve-conduction studies in the right arm are likely to suggest a brachial plexopathy but will not reveal its cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical spine disease can manifest with pain that radiates to the shoulder or radicular neurologic findings in the arm; however, the first priority in this case is to rule out a superior pulmonary sulcus tumor.

E) CORRECT:

In a patient with a significant history of cigarette smoking, the presence of shoulder pain with muscle wasting in the ipsilateral distal extremity and a normal shoulder examination should suggest the possibility of an upper thoracic tumor compressing or invading the brachial plexus. These tumors, called superior pulmonary sulcus or Pancoast tumors, are typically due to non-small-cell lung cancers. The pain that patients experience is due to invasion of the tumor into the brachial plexus or through extension of the tumor into the parietal pleura, ribs, or vertebra. These tumors can also invade the sympathetic chain and inferior cervical ganglion and cause Horner syndrome. The most appropriate next step is to obtain a chest radiograph.

Key learning point: Shoulder pain and wasting of the small muscles of the hand in a patient with a long history of cigarette smoking should prompt evaluation for superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast tumor) with a chest radiograph.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A heterogeneous mass-like opacity (red overlay) in the right apex extends to a thickened irregular pleural surface (blue overlay). Other vague areas of soft tissue density are also present in the right apex (green overlay), and the posterior cortices of the right 3rd, 4th, and 5th ribs (indicated by white dashed outlines) are not fully visualized as a result of tumor invasion.

The findings are consistent with a Pancoast tumor with chest wall extension.

questions.text: Seven hours after you perform a left hip arthroplasty for chronic hip pain, a 67-year-old woman reports a prickling sensation in her left anteromedial thigh and lower leg. On neurologic examination, left leg strength is 3/5 on hip flexion and 2/5 on knee extension. The patellar reflex is decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased on the anteromedial left thigh and medial lower leg. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

L5 radiculopathy typically causes back pain that radiates down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot, with sensory loss along the lateral aspect of the lower leg and dorsum of the foot and strength deficits in foot dorsiflexion and eversion. This patient's symptoms are localized to different areas and do not follow a radicular pattern.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibular nerve injury is usually caused by injuries in the lower leg (e.g., fracture of the fibular head or tight-fitting casts of the lower leg). It typically presents with foot drop (weakness of foot dorsiflexors) and a loss of sensation between the first and second toe (deep peroneal nerve branch) and the back of the feet and toes (superficial peroneal nerve branch). Fibular nerve injury would not cause loss of sensation in the anteromedial thigh or the decreased knee extension seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

S1 radiculopathy typically causes back pain that radiates down the posterior leg into the foot, with sensory loss along the lateral foot, weakness in plantar flexion and eversion, and a decreased Achilles tendon reflex. This patient's symptoms are localized to different areas and do not follow a radicular pattern.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has evidence of femoral nerve injury, likely from prolonged compression during surgery. Injury of the femoral nerve typically results in loss of sensation in the anteromedial thigh and medial lower leg (anterior cutaneous branches), as well as decreased strength in hip flexion (iliopsoas muscle) and knee extension (quadriceps femoris muscle).

Key learning point: Femoral nerve injury causes weakness in hip flexion and knee extension, decreased patellar reflex, and sensory loss over the anteromedial thigh and medial lower leg.

E) INCORRECT:

Obturator nerve injury usually results from pelvic ring fractures or entrapment. It typically manifests with loss of sensation of the medial thigh (cutaneous branch of the obturator nerve) and decreased strength in the hip adductors. It would not explain this patient's loss of sensation in the anterior thigh or her decreased strength in knee extension.
questions.hint: Postoperative anteromedial thigh and lower leg paresthesias with concurrent decreased patellar reflex, hip flexion, and knee extension are consistent with damage to a peripheral nerve of the anterior lower extremity.

questions.text: You are seeing a 21-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. She reports significant pain and weakness in her right arm and hand. On examination, there are multiple ecchymoses and tenderness in the right upper extremity. She is able to make a fist, but her grip strength is markedly decreased. An x-ray of the right upper extremity reveals a midshaft humerus fracture. Which one of the following structures is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brachial artery injury is a possible complication of humerus fractures but is more likely to occur in a supracondylar fracture (brachial artery runs along the anteromedial aspect of the humerus) than a mid-shaft fracture. Acute limb ischemia due to brachial artery injury can cause distal weakness (e.g., decreased grip strength). However, paralysis due to acute limb ischemia is usually associated with paresthesias, which are not reported by this patient. Injury of a different structure is more likely to be the underlying cause of symptoms in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

An ulnar nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control flexion of the little and ring fingers (medial belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, ulnar nerve palsy is typically associated with fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus rather than a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus.

C) INCORRECT:

A median nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, as seen here, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control thumb opposition (thenar muscles) and flexion of the index and middle fingers (flexor digitorum superficialis, lateral belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, median nerve palsy is typically associated with supracondylar fractures rather than a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus.

D) CORRECT:

Radial nerve injury is the most common complication associated with mid-shaft humerus fractures due to the radial nerve's proximity to the humerus shaft. It is typically associated with wrist drop, decreased finger extensor strength, and loss of sensation over the dorsal hand and forearm. Decreased grip strength can also be present due to impaired wrist extension (wrist extension ensures the optimal action of finger flexors) but the ability to make a fist is not affected.

See “Humerus fracture nerve palsies” table.

Key learning point: Midshaft humerus fractures commonly injure the radial nerve, leading to wrist drop and decreased grip strength due to impaired wrist extension.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

E) INCORRECT:

The radial artery is unlikely to be injured by a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus because it originates below the cubital fossa as a terminal branch of the brachial artery.
questions.hint: This patient most likely cannot extend her hand at the wrist joint.

questions.text: You are seeing a 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation who comes to your clinic for a prenatal visit. She reports several weeks of dull, aching pain and paresthesia over her left hand. The pain radiates to her shoulder and is worse at night. She also notes numbness in her hand upon waking in the morning. Vital signs are normal. When her wrist is passively held in full flexion, her paresthesia is immediately aggravated. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?

choices.text: Lower trunk palsy of the brachial plexus.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paralysis of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Klumpke palsy) causes deficits along the C8 and T1 myotomes and dermatomes. Although Klumpke palsy may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand and would also be present on the ulnar aspect of the forearm. Hand and finger weakness is also typically prominent. In addition, this patient lacks a history that would suggest Klumpke paralysis (e.g., upward traction on the arm, thoracic outlet syndrome, Pancoast tumor).

B) CORRECT:

Compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel (carpal tunnel syndrome, CTS) results in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the areas innervated by the median nerve (i.e., palmar surface of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, and radial half of the ring finger). Pregnancy is an important risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome because of physiological fluid retention, which leads to edema of soft tissue in and around the carpal tunnel. The sensory disturbances in CTS are classically worse at night and pain on flexion of the wrist (a positive Phalen test) may be present. Occasionally, the pain may radiate to the shoulder, as seen in this patient. Most cases of carpal tunnel syndrome with an onset during pregnancy can be managed by splinting of the wrist. Surgery and corticosteroid injections are usually not required because symptoms usually resolve after delivery.

Key learning point: Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by median nerve compression at the wrist, leading to nocturnal pain and paresthesia in the lateral hand, and is commonly associated with pregnancy due to fluid retention.
Image Description:

The Phalen maneuver is considered specific for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The examiner holds the patient's wrist in flexion (1) or extension (2). If paresthesia in the fingers innervated by the median nerve (marked in white) occurs or is aggravated within one minute, this finding is highly specific for CTS.

C) INCORRECT:

Radial nerve compression usually results from trauma or prolonged pressure on the mid-arm (e.g., Saturday night palsy). Radial nerve palsy typically manifests with sensory changes over the posterior forearm/hand and weakness on wrist extension (i.e., wrist drop). This patient has no significant risk factors for radial nerve compression (e.g., trauma or intoxication) and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with radial nerve compression.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiculopathy of C6, C7, and/or C8 nerve roots may manifest with pain and paresthesia in the hand and shoulder. However, radiculopathy is typically accompanied by restriction of neck, arm, or hand movements. Also, nocturnal paresthesia is usually not present. Exacerbation of paresthesia by passive flexion of the wrist (Phalen sign) suggests a specific mononeuropathy and not radiculopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Compression of the ulnar nerve in the ulnar groove between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon (cubital tunnel syndrome) may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand as seen in this patient. However, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand, and/or the ring and little finger and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with ulnar nerve compression. Also, this patient has no history that would suggest a cubital tunnel syndrome (e.g., osteoarthritis or trauma to the elbow).
questions.hint: Beside pregnancy, hypothyroidism and rheumatoid arthritis are also risk factors for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old construction worker presents after falling from scaffolding and landing on his right side with excessive lateral flexion of his neck. Physical examination shows impaired flexion and supination of the right forearm, impaired external rotation of the right arm, impaired right arm abduction, and impaired right wrist extension. The right biceps reflex is absent. Sensory examination shows decreased sensation over the right thumb and lateral surface of the right forearm and arm. What is the most likely anatomical location of injury?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Axillary nerve injury causes isolated deltoid weakness affecting shoulder abduction but does not cause biceps weakness, wrist extensor weakness, or the pattern of sensory loss described.

B) INCORRECT:

Lower trunk brachial plexus injury affects C8–T1 nerve roots and causes intrinsic hand muscle weakness with sensory loss in the ulnar distribution, not the proximal muscle weakness and C5–C6 sensory pattern described in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This pattern of weakness affecting shoulder abduction (deltoid, supraspinatus), elbow flexion (biceps), and wrist extension with sensory loss in the C5–C6 dermatome distribution indicates injury to the upper trunk brachial plexus involving the C5-C6 nerve roots.

D) INCORRECT:

Median nerve injury causes thenar muscle weakness and sensory loss in the median nerve distribution but does not cause proximal muscle weakness or lateral forearm sensory loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Isolated radial nerve injury causes wrist drop and weakness of wrist and finger extensors but does not cause bicep weakness or shoulder abduction deficits.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of burning pain and numbness of her right thigh. She reports that the pain improves when she wears loose fitting pants. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation to light touch of the lateral surface of the right anterior thigh with normal reflexes and strength examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Femoral nerve injury typically presents with impaired hip flexion and knee extension with decreased patellar tendon reflex.

B) INCORRECT:

Obturator nerve injury typically presents with weakness of hip adductors with pain and paresthesia over the medial thigh.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve injury, also known as meralgia paresthetica, presents with pain and paresthesias of the lateral surface of the anterior thigh without motor deficits. It commonly occurs during pregnancy due to increased intraabdominal pressure causing compression at the inguinal ligament level.

D) INCORRECT:

Common peroneal nerve injury causes foot drop, steppage gait, and impaired foot eversion or dorsiflexion with sensory loss over the lateral lower leg and dorsum of the foot.

E) INCORRECT:

Sciatic nerve injury would cause motor deficits including impaired knee flexion and hip adduction, along with sensory loss over the lower leg and foot.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of opioid use disorder presents to the emergency department with right hand weakness since waking up this morning. He states he used fentanyl the night before and fell asleep with his right arm draped over a bench. Physical examination shows inability to extend the right wrist and fingers with decreased sensation over the dorsal aspect of the thumb, index, and middle fingers. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Radial nerve injury likely resulted from Saturday night palsy from compression of the radial nerve within the axilla. The clinical findings of wrist drop, and sensory loss over the dorsal aspect of the thumb, index, and middle fingers support the diagnosis of a radial nerve injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Ulnar nerve injury typically causes impaired flexion of the wrist, and adduction and abduction of the fingers with sensory deficits in the little finger and medial ring finger.

C) INCORRECT:

Axillary nerve injury typically causes impaired arm abduction and sensory loss over the lateral arm.

D) INCORRECT:

Median nerve injury typically causes impaired flexion of the wrist, thumb, index, and middle fingers with sensory loss on the palmar aspects of the thumb, index, and middle fingers.

E) INCORRECT:

Musculocutaneous nerve injury typically causes impaired elbow flexion with sensory loss over the lateral forearm.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. She has significant pain and weakness in her right arm and hand. Physical examination shows multiple ecchymoses and tenderness in the right upper extremity. She is able to make a fist, but there is marked decrease in grip strength. An x-ray of the right upper extremity shows a midshaft humerus fracture. Which of the following structures is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A median nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, as seen here, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control thumb opposition (thenar muscles) and flexion of the index and middle fingers (flexor digitorum superficialis, lateral belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, median nerve palsy is typically associated with supracondylar fractures rather than a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus.
Image Description:

AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

B) CORRECT:

Radial nerve injury is the most common complication associated with mid-shaft humerus fractures due to the radial nerve's proximity to the humerus shaft. It is typically associated with wrist drop, decreased finger extensor strength, and loss of sensation over the dorsal hand and forearm. Decreased grip strength can also be present due to impaired wrist extension (wrist extension ensures the optimal action of finger flexors) but the ability to make a fist is not affected.

See “Humerus fracture nerve palsies” table.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

C) INCORRECT:

The radial artery is unlikely to be injured by a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus because it originates below the cubital fossa as a terminal branch of the brachial artery.

D) INCORRECT:

Brachial artery injury is a possible complication of humerus fractures but is more likely to occur in a supracondylar fracture (brachial artery runs along the anteromedial aspect of the humerus) than a mid-shaft fracture. Acute limb ischemia due to brachial artery injury can cause distal weakness (e.g., decreased grip strength). However, paralysis due to acute limb ischemia is usually associated with paresthesias, which are not reported by this patient. Injury of a different structure is more likely to be the underlying cause of symptoms in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

An ulnar nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control flexion of the little and ring fingers (medial belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, ulnar nerve palsy is typically associated with fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus rather than a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

F) INCORRECT:

Isolated musculocutaneous nerve injury is rare and typically occurs as a result of trauma from chest compression or shoulder dislocation. Although such injuries can occur in motor vehicle accidents, they would manifest with impaired elbow flexion, not with decreased grip strength.
questions.hint: This patient most likely cannot extend her hand at the wrist joint.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He has significant pain and weakness in his right arm and hand.
Physical examination reveals:

Multiple ecchymoses and tenderness on the right upper extremity

+2/4 deep tendon reflexes in the upper extremities
Ability to make a fist bilaterally
Marked decrease in grip strength in the right hand

An x-ray of the right upper extremity shows a midshaft humerus fracture. Which of the following structures is most likely injured?

A) INCORRECT:

The radial artery is unlikely to be injured by a midshaft fracture of the humerus because it originates below the cubital fossa as a terminal branch of the brachial artery.

B) INCORRECT:

An ulnar nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control flexion of the little and ring fingers (medial belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, ulnar nerve palsy is typically associated with fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus rather than a midshaft fracture of the humerus.

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

C) INCORRECT:

Brachial artery injury is a possible complication of humerus fractures but is more likely to occur in a supracondylar fracture (brachial artery runs along the anteromedial aspect of the humerus) than a midshaft fracture. Acute limb ischemia due to brachial artery injury can cause distal weakness (e.g., decreased grip strength). However, paralysis due to acute limb ischemia is usually associated with paresthesias, which are not reported by this patient. Injury of a different structure is more likely to be the underlying cause of symptoms in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

A median nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, as seen here, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control thumb opposition (thenar muscles) and flexion of the index and middle fingers (flexor digitorum superficialis, lateral belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, median nerve palsy is typically associated with supracondylar fractures rather than a midshaft fracture of the humerus.

AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

E) CORRECT:

Radial nerve injury is the most common complication associated with midshaft humerus fractures due to the radial nerve's proximity to the humerus shaft. Other common causes of injury to the radial nerve include direct pressure on the nerve in the axilla (e.g., due to improper use of crutches) and compression of the nerve against the humerus (e.g., Saturday night palsy).

See “Humerus fracture nerve palsies” table.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

F) INCORRECT:

Isolated musculocutaneous nerve injury is rare and typically occurs as a result of trauma from chest compression or shoulder dislocation. Although such injuries can occur in motor vehicle accidents, they would manifest with impaired elbow flexion, not with decreased grip strength.
questions.hint: Patients presenting with this injury would most likely also have right-sided wrist drop.
